Qud is a desperately cruel and radiated world full of mutations and factions of hate, but also a beautifully poetic living world, where you truly are a part of it, trying to survive as best you can, with only Darwin's help in understanding the selection pressures and the mutations you can mould yourself into.

The game is almost a work of art, a procedurally crafted world laid on a framework of lore from a world inspired by the tabletop RPG Gamma World (along with others). You can roll truekin humans with cybernetics or mutant humans with all sorts of biomutant properties. You have quests to follow, and lore to explore, and the flora and fauna of the various biomes you encounter to use or abuse at your whim. You'll have factional reputation with all species, and your mutations or cybernetics can be adapted to customise your playstyle.

This game is a survival game in the truest sense coupled with traditional roguelike tactical action, and pushing the envelope in lore, character customisation and tactical options available to you. The writing and generated lore will have you exploring purely for curious enjoyment. You will marvel at the inhabitants and the monster diversity on offer. The game is constantly being updated with more content, both systems and lore. The Freeholdgames guys are dedicated to making this a world to play in, rather than a one off game to enjoy and throw away. 

Endless possiblities abounds.

Gather your waterskins and torches and lets get crackin' with this adventure!

Phenomenal writing.  Truly unique and original setting rich with lore.  Total character customizability and freedom of choice.  Brutal, punishing difficulty that revels in killing you over and over again, so you can start again with a better understanding of what it takes to survive in the harsh, unforgiving world of Qud.

Be a teleporting mind-reader, or a four-armed sword-wielding behemoth with horns.  Hack off your enemies' limbs and bludgeon them to death with them, or slice off their face and wear it as a mask.  Put on mechanical wings and fly above the battlefield, hosing your enemies with a tank-fed flamethrower, or do the same thing as a mutant with your own organic wings and the ability to shoot gouts of fire from your palms.  Chisel through grainy sandstone walls with a pickaxe, or superheat metal with fire until it's reduced to a puddle of molten slag.  Overwhelm your enemies with psionic attacks that render them little more than jabbering, disoriented cretins that stumble and trip over their own feet.  Gather liquids to concoct your own tonics and remedies from ancient texts, or play around with them to see what happens if you mix a little of jar A and jar B.

Get infected by fungal spores and grow glowing tendrils on your back.  Contract a disease that makes your tongue swell and rot away, leaving you only with the dialogue option of "Nnnnnnnnnnn."  Douse yourself with your remaining supply of fresh water to put out your flaming clothes.  Get sucked into a rip in the space-time continuum and ejected at an unknown location miles underground with no light source.  Find yourself hunted by interdimensional psychics hell-bent on ending you at every turn.

This game is not for the faint of heart, but if you have a shred of imagination, do yourself a favor and get this game.  Endure the initial learning curve and accept that you're going to die.  A lot.  Trust me, it's worth it.

What separates it from Dwarf Fortress is a much easier to grasp interface - every shortcut can be checked, changes, and easily learned. The graphics itself are also much more readable, as they are tileset based, not ASCII.

Don't expect Dwarf Fortress here. Don't expect a regular rougelike experience. Caves of Qud brings this lovely taste of something unique - combination of the sci-fi setting straight out of the 80's imagination (my personal impression), the eerie world and encounters, most weird combinations of creatures and their themes, the absolutely OP skills and abilities you may acquire over time, or encounter as used by your enemies (I still remember the first time I was attacked by an enemy Esper, who proceeded to play with my mind and rip me to shreds). A world where currency is fresh water, a world where you fall in love in most unexpected moments...

This game is deep.

The history of the world is a game mechanic. Gather clues about Sultans, legendary weapons, and lost artifacts from books and paintings and statues strewn across the landscape. Pin-point the location of the treasure on the map and go searching for it.

There is a main questline and plenty of story and setting defined to get started but the procedurally generated content weaves itself over these bones and forms a living, moving creature. This is exactly what you want to plant stories in your players' minds. The people, places, and culture create the setting... there's a lot to unearth here but there's no Tolkien-esque world-building: it's generated by a tight relationship between the game and the player.

Gamma World was the PnP RPG that inspired this game. I think after all of these years that Qud has been in development Freehold have managed to surpass is predecessor in terms of mechanics, story-telling and atmosphere. It has a quality all its own.

I cannot recommend this game enough. It really should win GotY.

Caves of Qud can be intimidating to try to engage with. It is unabashedly esoteric, with countless stats and it's quasi-ASCII aesthetics. The world is one of the strangest you will ever encounter, with strange creatures and even stranger humans. The worl is massive, especially for a a permadeath game, with countless screens to walk through to your destinations, and potentially infinite caverns to descend with all kinds of hellish adversaries to fight. It's also blisteringly hard. Death can come in an instant. You might spend hours with a character only to stumble upon an aggressive and impossibly strong enemy and get destroyed instantly. In short, Caves of Qud is a scary game in these ways.

But once you get past that hard exterior, Caves of Qud is an immensely addicting and engrossing game. There are so many ways to build your character, so many directions to explore, and so many ways to die. For those like myself who have never touched a 'true' rogue-like before, Caves of Qud might be that first game that let's into it's dank & deep corridors and drives you up the wall. You might need to read a beginner's guide, and you might need to keep a wiki open, but the sheer depth and beauty of Qud is something that doesn't come very often, and is more than worth your attention. Look past it's complexity and into the nightmare that lies dorman within, simply waiting for you to sink your teeth into it's flesh.

[h1]I wish there would be a mixed setting for reviewing. Because Caves of Qud is the most complicate game to rate i've ever seen.[/h1]


That's why I will be straightforward.

[u]Why would you buy Caves of Qud ?[/u]

If you want to try the hardest  rogue-like rpg up to date  with minimalistic graphics and rich story then you can buy this game.

Otherwise forget it.

Because you can have a lot of fun and really rewarding moments as you can become so frustrated and angry to smash your keyboard (wich is actually the only controler).


[h1]If you still want to buy this game: Few things you must know before playing.[/h1]

[u]The Game Developpement/ Community:[/u]

Caves of Qud is in early access. Supported by a great dev team (these guys are awesome ! ).
The minimalistic render of the game permits amazing possibilities regularly updated by new stories, content and bug fixes (Sorry you won't fall in love for a wood sign again ). Caves of Qud is one of the most promising early access around. Most of the ones who played it have barely scratched it's surface ! Also the developpement logs are some of the funniest i've ever read.

If you enter this world you will find  a friendly community. Forums are  full of nice and helpfull people. Plus there's already implemented Steam Workshop to add new stories, items, character presets or skills. 

[u]Overall difficulty and Survival tips:[/u]

Caves of Qud is a brutally difficult game. Maybe the hardest i've ever played. Hours of efforts can be lots in seconds. There is no space for errors and lack of planning.

Especially when you build your character. Don't trust reviews talking about weird stuff with character creation.
Of course you can do amazing things in this game. But taking risks leads to a game over and nothing else.
No exp for your highscores. No unlockables after death. Just lessons, regrets and your tears...

You can save your starting character sheet and also the world seed: wich is one of the most important feature regarding difficulty. Everything is random except tilesets if you save your world seed. It makes adventures way more manageable for your successives tries. So keep that in mind !

Surviving requires you to gather food and water. Depending of your character you might have different habits to fullfill your needs. Also be ware water is a currency and can overload you. It makes trading a bit tedious because you must trade water for items with the same trading price but lightweight.
To set a base in a village is a good thing, you can lift chests and drop them anywhere. If you store items inside nobody will steal them.

Remember to always have a backup plan when you create a character. By plan I mean: a way to escape fights !
Because almost everything is random you fall rather often on huge packs or a really vicious enemies just around a corner, down some stairs or in the wilderness on the border of  a new tile.
That's why you must be able to set up a decent escape plan for every situations.
Run, jump, lay mines, throw grenades, freeze with your hands, stun with your cudgel or just teleport yourself and run away ! (teleportation is my favourite skill in Caves of Qud. Nothing can beat this).

You can inspect the world around you. Helps you to know  your enemies , there's a cybernetic augment that give you detailed informations about your target. If it's tough or impossible and angry .... Run ! !


Note that you need to light your environment or get the appropriate skill to see whenever the conditions. Temperature matters, check your body temperature or when it's too late pour something on you !

Doing regular faction checks and inspecting new people helps to prevent bad surprises. 


And take your time, you might survive longer....


[u]Character creation:[/u]

Even if the possibilities are almost limitless when you create your character you have to choose between Mutated humans and True Kins.

Mutants can tailor their skills by adding new limbs/organs or spychic powers (teleportation and some other cool stuff). One of the starting mutations is really interresting: you can be versatile, choose an unstable genome and get amazing results or focus on one type and exclude the other (Physical or Mind mutations). You can also select a Caste that gives skills/bonuses/equipements and serves as your background.

True Kins could be seen as fresh "Fallout" Vault Dwellers.
Stronger starting attributes and unable to get mutations. They get more skill points every level and have access to cybernetics: the weaker cousin of mutations, at least for the moment.
You can also choose castes and they get slightly better starting equipement (wich is sometimes really unfair compared to mutants).


Your equipement is really important no matter what character you create. Try to spend enough Ego points so you will sell your loot at decent prices. No other attribute can affect bartering.


Take time to understand how attributes and skills works. If you fail to stick to one character type you won't be able to reach your full potential. Saving and practicing a character in the first tries is a good thing... especially True Kins, they are easier to handle when you start.


[u]Progression:[/u]

Caves of Qud is very grindy. You will often kills tons of enemies to reach a decent level and skills/mutations sets.
Be ware quests are extremely hard, you must explore the world first and get some gear and experience to be able to finish them.

The deeper you explore, the more you venture to the East... the more dangerous it will be.

Tinkering is the only crafting skill available in the game. A bit of a problem sometimes because related to intelligence and gives access to tons of receipes unavailable to other builds without itl. Especially restorative injectors and grenades. You can buy them if you find some appropriate traders but crafting is still the best way to survive longer.
Also Tinkering enable to lay mines (in fact to put grenades on the ground), wich is really helpfull when you want to flee ! 



[h1]The word of the end[/h1]

Caves of Qud is a unique game. Not for everyone that's for sure.

Detailed on many aspects and extremely deep. The pleasure of discovering new characters, locations and even new ways to survive is a delight.
However loosing a character that fast and forever is really annoying especially after so many hours spent on trying to get the best of every situations.

That's why I'm still mixed and turned my review into a small guide to prevent you most of the frustrating moments when you start.
Keep your time to learn how to survive in this world otherwise you will miss everything about this game.

"Life and Drink" my friend

N.B: Don't forget to save your characters builds and copy and paste in a folder your World seeds. Teleportation might be your best ally... trust me.

As a roguelike fan, i can say that this game shows potential, but still needs way more polishing.

I'll list some of the the cons:
1. Static overworld. A fair choice, but for now it feels empty. If you go with static then every village should have a fair amount of interesting NPCs with many different quests. Right now there's like 1 main quest with a sidequest or two. The main quest jumps in difficulty from a level 1 dungeon to a place where it's recommended to go at lvl 17 with a set of gear. So from levels 7-17 you're supposed to go grinding in a random cave or ruin, and after you finish it, maybe grind again for a little more. If i wanted to grind for the sake of grinding, i'd rather play poschengband.

2. Stats and skills. Physical mutants feel kinda boring. Many mutations have drawbacks, so you have to use mutation points to level them up, so their advantages become stronger. That means you either level up your 3-4 starting muts(boring) or have many semi-useless random mutations(ineffective). Any drawbacks except maybe a beak are cripplingly bad and they basically mean you play on challenge mode. That makes build variety for phys mutants really limited. Look at cataclysm DDA how to make mutations right. Every bonus is not super good, but every drawback is not super crippling.

Another point is skills, so as a mutant you cannot afford more than 16 int, because there are no real dump stats. So any mutant builds feel kinda one-dimensional because you're starved of skill points.

3. Design flaws. Just naming a few.
-Slumberlings. So this monster is supposed to teach that not every dude should be killable. They can spawn in red rock and rust wells(first two dungeons) and if disturbed by someone else they charge you and literally oneshot you. Fun times. Now let's look how DCSS adresses the similiar issue. They have a red imp, who regenerates, blinks and has decent magic resist BUT he deals almost NO damage. Surely, this is the more elegant way to teach that principle, don't you think?
-Water-based economy. This is a cool concept, but in game with a low str character it translates to the endless recoiling, dropping water to stash, getting water from stash to merchants, all this pointless micromanagement.
-Confusion. The confusion in this game is absolutely ridiculous. You don't just take random actions and may fail using of items\spells\potions. The entire map turns into gibberish, along with your inventory. The one time i got to bethesda susa boss, i easily killed the welcoming party at the elevator, but then the boss permaconfused me and nicked me to death, and the worst part is that you cannot even escape because every item in your inventory gets renamed to "fgsfds" of something.

Of course there are some minor flaws that add some inconvenience like why do i have to choose the waterskin every time i pick one dram of blood and why do i pour 20 drams of water in 3 waterskins instead of filling one with 60. So the final verdict, as i said, Caves of Qud has potential to become a great roguelike, but if you're looking for a sort of finished product with a flawless gameplay(i know this is still the early access, but it has been in it for a while), i cannot reccomend this game for now.

I love this game but I thought my review could be more helpful to prevent people from buying the game because they do not realize what kind of game it is. Therefore, I took the time to dispel a few things that people might not realize about the game. I can not say it enough that I absolutely love the game but I want to at first go through some things that I notice get negative reviews and explain them.

This game has old school ASCII art like the nethack game except they use custom tiles and not all ASCII art from what I can tell. If you like something with high quality graphics then this game might be confusing or difficult. I am not saying you will not like it but you should beware. To me the graphics are high quality but they are just not 3D or dense. It requires some imagination to sort of realize a more comprehensive environment. This is expected from this type of game and you can tell by looking at the videos and screenshots; however, beware if your not sure. Steam offers a refund but make sure you stop playing before two hours.

The user interface is actually really easy but at first it will be really hard if you have never played any games like this before. It is all keyboard commands; however, its not too terribly difficult to learn. But, if your not into using the keyboard and learning the commands then its likely going to not be fun. It does have an experimental interface that you can use a mouse on from what I have seen but I never play with it because the keyboard works great for doing everything with minimal movement on my part.

The game is hard but it is not hard like Dark Souls; however, by default, just like other rouge games it has permadeath by default. However, you can turn the permadeath off in options. The key to this game is to farm a while at the beginning at least. You need to gain a few levels. Also, use the L key to look around at NPCs to determine if they are hostile and how powerful they are. Without using the L key you are going to end up walking blind into battles that you can not win. Even if you use the best tactics and have tons of experience you will still eventually die.

It is an RPG but its really a rouge game which means it does not play like a normal RPG where you can load a previous save when you die unless you disable permadeath.  It has all the RPG features but the game's super genre is rouge which is where the permadeath and randomized play through comes from. It is also the reasoning for a significant amount of randomness. 

The randomness can make you lose to something that is lower leveled then you if you are already in a weak condition or state; however, being prepared if the key. You have to be really cautious in this game. If you like a fast paced hack and slash game then be careful. This game can be fast paced but its might not be the style of fast paced you like because of the randomness sometimes. You can see some powerful enemies in the beginning area so you have to be prepared by gaining levels and taking it easy.

It is also very open world - to the point where some players can feel lost or aimless. It does have quests but only a few at the beginning since you have to find the others, therefore, sometimes your going to be exploring just to explore and see what is out there. It is also a fairly big world and a large part of the experience is down in the underground areas. These appear as stairs going down.

Some of the books (not sure how many) are randomized and many of the things about the game can be that way too. It can make you feel like there is no story to the game. There is a story but its in the quest line and from some of the static things in the game. The random books and things are just kind of interesting because they make you try to figure out if its something important. If you are not proficient in English then you might find the game a challenge.

I have experienced one bug in my ten hours of play. The game locked up and I guess it did not autosave before I had gained a level and one of my mutations stabilized, therefore, I lost my four arms I had gained. My point being is that there are likely a few bugs and they could cause you to lose your game and progress. Its not as terrible as others games since it is a rouge type game and you will eventually die but be prepared for a few bugs at least. I would generally say the game is almost bug free from my experience but that also comes with early access. Its essentially an almost finished game but just beware.

====

One of the craziest games I have ever played. A real rouge-like adventure. You can play with four arms, contract fungal spore infections that cause you all sorts of misery and do damage at the same time, get all sorts of crazy abilities I have never seen in a game before, and its all fairly randomized so no play through is the same.

** Novel mechanic: Analgesia - No hitpoint numbers! Only general state! **

There are a lot of games that claim to be random and this one does have static places and events. Its a hard game so you will die a lot and believe me each play through is different. That is something I have never experienced with any other game. It has permadeath enabled - BUT its actually fun. It is also a game where skill and experience helps you to last longer and get further. It has randomness but its not overwhelming or crazy.

Want to gain a mutation to release corrosive gas that eats through walls, have precognition to travel backwards in time to fix a mistake you made before you die, or play with amnesia? This game amazingly brings some of the most novel game mechanics I have ever seen.

I guess the developer was able to spend more time with actual game mechanics and content instead of graphics and it turned out to be a great game. 

I recommend playing the weekly and daily challenges. You get a interesting build and you can play it at least a few times before it changes. Also, you get ranked on how high of a score you got. Where the score is computed from various things such as turns survived, experience gained, complexity of items in inventory, and all sorts of things. It is interesting playing a new build and trying to see how well you can place on the leaderboard for the weekly and daily challenge. 

This is also one of those games that is cheap to buy and gives you lots of hours of play here and there when you get board. Its not too demanding on the computer either so even a junk box can run it.

In the last two months, a major feature arc was added to the game, The Water Ritual. Fresh drinkable water is scarce in Qud, so much so that the standard unit of currency in the game is about an ounce of water. To gift your life-preserving water to someone is a show of great respect and brotherhood, doing so is so culturally important in Qud that it happens in a form of ceremony that is acknowledged and respected by all of the 40+ factions of Qud. Commencing this ritual boosts your reputation with the faction whose leader you gifted the water, but it also decreases it with the enemies of that person. Each named NPC in Qud has a generated history and reputation with every faction in the game, which is different each time you play. This means, depending on who you encounter in a given game, you can make friends with even the most initially hostile of factions. 

Now lets talk crazy. You know how most games when they do something unbalanced that breaks the game, they usually nerf that power by making it less powerful? Caves of Mud had that problem with its Psychic class of mutant. So did the debs make the Psychics less powerful? No. They created an in-game multiverse and sent extra-dimensional enemy Psychics to hunt you down if your psychic power grew to such prominence that it threatened the stability of the universe. That was a nerf. Adding a multiverse was a nerf. They did that three weeks ago.
I have bought this game for friends and family just so I could be able to talk to them about it. I have offered to buy this game for complete strangers who were on the fence about it. If you aren’t already playing it, you owe it to yourself to give it a try. Don’t let early access tag fool you, this game has more polish and devotion poured into it than Chrome on the Towering Spindle that pierces the skies to the far east. Descend into the Caves of Qud, claim their secrets, tempt fate and survive.

30+ hours in for 10$? Hard to give that a negative review for certain, and I don't intend to. Qud does a far better job of creating world immersion by having an actual world setting, rather than endless and fairly nameless levels of dungeons like other roguelikes. Although at times charmingly clunky, the pregenerated books and stories of the world add a wonderful touch to the world feeling alive and lived in. Very much takes after Dwarf Fortress adventure mode, but with far more progress and polish.

That said, the game isn't without its flaws. With additional complexity, ontop of the Roguelike genre's brutal approach to "difficulty", this game should not be your first delve into the genre. I highly, highly recommend Caves of Qud to fans of old-school RPGs, regardless of whether or not you have experience with roguelikes. As soon as I found out what it was and got into it, Qud cemented itself as an immediate classic in my mind. Even in its incomplete state it's won me over completely; definitely in my top 15 favorite games of all time, at least. Don't let the early-access designation and minimal graphics throw you off; it's an absolutely engrossing, deep, gorgeous experience that's worth every penny and more. It is permadeath and is intended to be played that way, though there are ways to disable that. But the difficulty is, for the most part, fair and predictable enough that I never felt the need to do so. My biggest complaint is how monotonous the early-game can be, and it's the part of the game where RNG has the highest chance of getting you killed, which is both a good and bad thing I guess.
It's far from complete, but it's also being very actively developed, with weekly updates and lots of developer communication. What's here already is a substantial, enjoyable and truly unique experience. As far as overall feel, I suppose parallels could be drawn between it and games like Wasteland and Fallout, but the setting is truly unique, bizarre and esoteric, with a quirky and fascinating mix of post-apocalypse and otherworldly fantasy elements. You've got lasers and robots alongside plate armor and talking plants, and while it's often wacky it never feels nonsensical or obnoxiously absurd. The biggest hurdle for most people to overcome would probably be the somewhat convoluted controls, but they're more than tolerable once you get a hang of them and the devs are actively making efforts to make the controls and interface more accessible, which I think is great. This game deserves a huge following and anything that makes it more accessible is wonderful. It's also super easy to mod, if you feel like getting in to that.

While the game isn't fully complete yet, it already has a special place in my heart next to ADOM. In the hierarchy of great roguelikes, this one is destined to be at or near the top, depending on how much they keep adding content and flesing out their world. 

Pros:  Like ADOM, this is an open questing roguelike world, but turned up to 11.  There's a main story quest and various branching sub-quests, but you can literally just start exploring and keep going down until you encounter something that eventually kills you. The game is effectively infinite since every square on the world map correponds to a large overland area tons of random and not-random content, and underneath each of these screens are even more randomly generated linking caves, so you can effectively explore in any direction (except up) until you die from old age or your computer eventually runs out of memory. (which is going to take a long time since my biggest savegame is currently 43MB)

Gameplay is very like ADOM, ...but in a post-apocalyptic setting with lazer weapons and robots, crafting (if you have the Tinkering skill), and the ability to replace your own bodyparts with cybernetic implants! Plus, water as a currency and a consumable is a nice touch. Also, instead of corruption, you can catch various diseases and fungal infections that can make your life miserable until you find the correct cure (Hint: There's a book in the game that tells you how)

It's moddable! And even this early access version has some great workshop content.

There's lots of character customization and fun mutant powers to be had, though this early access version could use some tweaking in terms of balance and starting points. Since it's all XML, I ended up modding my version to add additional mutant points per level so it felt a little more like my character was actually growing and getting something more than a few extra hitpoints with each level.

Meet friends and make enemies. Through the miracle of the water ritual you can even sometimes persuade them to join you. My best game had a sidekick flying serpent who was essentially Trogdor the Burninator, but unfortuately, while he was great at carrying supplied, he sucked when it came to randomly letting fly with jets of flame and acid gas attacks that inevitalby damaged me and destroyed valuable items on the floor.

You can sever body parts. And if you sever a creature's face off, you can then wear that body part on your own face as a mask. Yes, this even includes your own face if you happen to have the two heads mutation and can survive having one of your faces chopped off.

Cons:  The variety of Monsters in early access is currently extremely limited. This area needs to be massively expanded, as it gets boring fighting the exact same crabs, spiders, and slime blobs, but I'm sure it will be.

Monsters that create pools of liquid (especially slime and acid) needs to be scaled back big-time. Default puddles size should be maybe 1, 2, or 3 tiles, not 9. 31318086.review:
I've played a number of roguelikes over the years, with ADOM being my most played game ever (over the past decade).  Caves of Qud has been on my following list for ~2 years and after seeing consistent weekly updates from the developer and a recently released roadmap of future features planned I decided to pick this up.

I've played ~26 hours at this point trying out a variety of characters and haven't had this much fun playing a game in a long time.  I think the difficulty in this game is just right - I am given more leniency to try things out without being killed immediately as in some of the more hardcore roguelikes, but I am still punished with YASD for acting foolishly - but learning from deaths is part of every roguelike.

You start the game deciding to play a mutated human or a True Kin/non-mutated human.  Mutants can be made into physical monstrosities (paralyzing scorpion stinger, burrowing claws, regeneration, body full of quills, etc)  psychic beings (teleporting, charming, shooting concentrated light/lasers, conjuring fire, etc) with you being able to improve each mutation upon leveling up, or spend a few mutation points to choose between 3 random ones.  With a wide variety of mutations you can make some really unique builds.   True Kins don't have access to mutations, but generally start with better gear and attributes, and gain skills at a much faster rate - sills like dismembering (cut of someone's face or legs... and eat them!), charging strike, meditation, tinkering/crafting, etc. As with mutants, you can choose to play a strong dumb oaf, an agile gunslinger, an artifact collector slinging grenades or freezing his enemies.

The world itself has a few set static locations but for the most part is procedurally generated (including procedurally generated quests that lead you to interesting locations) that keeps things fresh and interesting.  You may stumble upon a ruins, a legendary creature's lair, or simply get lost when wandering on the overland map.  Instead of traveling on the overland map, you can choose to travel on the local map where every few screens/zones is considered passing one tile on the overland map.  side from the overland map, there is also an underground biome that spans the entire game world, filled with treasures and monsters.  

As nice bonus for players who aren't used to traditional roguelikes and memorizing 50 keys, CoQ streamlined actions into a single key that will perform the most logical action in the square you are targeting, such as looting and chatting to NPCs.  The game is easy to get into, and if you prefer to have less clutter in the UI you have the option you can change around the overlay to a few different options.

I would recommend this game to anyone who likes roguelikes - for early access it is an extremely well fleshed out game with tons of content and AMAZING lore.  I think the reviews speak for themselves with a 98% overall thumbs up.

>Create character
>Imur the Timesplitting Arconaut
>Travel to red rock to kill baddies
>Slaughtering everything with my time bending powers.
>Last floor has dozens of enemies in a single room.
>Summon a clone of myself through space and time to assist in combat.
>Clone has everything I have equiped,
>I have a frag grenade equipped.
>"You died, killed by Imur."

This game is what a true roguelike should be, a procedurally generated adventure that is only limited by your creativity. This starts with character creation, you can choose to be a True Kin, a pure human with advanced skills, or a mutant with the ability to modify their genes and attain obsurd powers and abilities. These mutations can manifest as physical traits, such as multiple arms to use more weapons, Nightvision to see in the dark, Regeneration to restore lost limbs and hitpoints. Mutations also add supernatural/psychic powers such as creating portals in space-time to banish enemies to a random location in the world(Or yourself) Pyromancy/Cryomancy, creating barriers or even cloning yourself to assist in combat. Both mental and physical mutations can be negatives to increase your creation points (Or challenge yourself). You may also choose a background that will buff your stats and start you off with random gear and some skills.

After character creation the game opens up to you. The world of Qud is a retro-future, post-human apocalyptic Tophet, the denizens here struggle everyday and the running currency is precious clean, drinkable water. The landscape is rife with tunnels, wells, caves , ruins, towns,  holy sites and fallen cities, quest specific areas (caves are procedural) are always the same but the land is dotted with randomized locations so each playthrough offers new exploration. Every creature belongs to a faction that exists in the world, flaura and fauna, and you can piss them all off, or try and befriend them, or instigate war between them.  

 You can choose to follow the main questline, or just wander the world in search of treasure/glory/scrap/artifacts or forbidden knowledge. The first few levels can be difficult, the first major quest you can recieve sends you to a low level dungeon to kill a creature and bring its corpse back to town, but this can prove difficult when a shotgun weilding,upright walking canine beast shoots a hole through your chest. I recommend killing creatures outside the starting town to gain a few levels. Whn you're ready, head out into the rust and find yourself, and die in increasingly hilarious ways. The game offers much more than I have experienced at this point and thats the beauty of it.

Caves of Qud is a masterwork Roguelike up there with Dungeoncrawl and Dwarf Fortress, winning isn't always possible but you'll always have a story after each playthrough.

All in all, for $10 bucks theres no reason this game shouldn't be in your library if you're looking for an endlessly fun Roguelike/RPG title.

TL:DR
If you combine Fallout, Dwarf fortress and Dungeoncrawl into a single game you get CoQ. Play it.

"I've journeyed farther than i've ever made it before. Across Moghra'yi, The Great Salt Desert, through teeming forests and dense jungles, past ancient ruins and foreboding caverns. Qud is full of exotic dangers, and i've had my fair share of close calls and narrow escapes along the way. I don't know that i would have made it through my last few encounter if not for my trusty new Vibroblade, which i recently bought off of a merchant who happened to be a sentient potted plant living in a city of talking albino gorillas.  The additional health provided by my mutant second heart also proved to be very useful. But now I'm in trouble. I'm surrounded by snapjaws, a sort of mutant human-hyena hybrid that i've encountered numerous times before with little problem. This time, however, their ranks are joined by an imposing figure named Fungus-Ridden Oofooflowuf. He appears to be some kind of snapjaw leader or hero, and a quick examination reveals that he inspires any other snapjaws in his vicinity to fight more effectively. He also happens to be infected by a parasitic fungus which allows him to emit deadly toxic spores from his body at will, and he is hated by The Wardens for having previously burned one of their leaders in effigy. All in all, not the most pleasant individual to come across. I try to beat a hasty retreat, but there's a wall blocking my path. If only i had the Burrowing Claws mutation i had chosen in a previous life so i could dig my way through the wall, or perhaps the wings so i could attempt to simply fly over my enemies and escape. Just another day in Qud.
...
Above all else, Qud is an absolute wonder of emergent storytelling. Every playthrough is completely different, and each one will ultimately form a completely unique story. Some of my favorite video game moments and stories of all time have emerged from Qud. Every character in the world has a detailed history, and you never know who you will encounter or how it will play out. There are a wealth of factors at play in every aspect of the game, and each one influences how your story will ultimately unfold, from the mutations at your disposal to the way your build affects your relationships and standing to the personal histories of each NPC and so on. I've barely scratched the surface of what this game can do in terms of it's mechanics  - I've probably uncovered maybe 10% of what is possible, even after watching tutorials, playthroughs and series I keep discovering new things, places, creatures, items. The simplicity of the sprites and graphical side hide just how complex and intricate this game is, this is a prime example of "Don't judge a book by it's cover". This game...This world... It's intoxicatingly beautiful, mechnically complex and intricatley and lovingly crafted and just overwhelms you, making you want more and more...and more.
This isn't a love letter to the old ASCI Roguelikes, this is the true rebirth.


Pros -

Actual Rogue like, bearing this title with a proud and well deserved fist to the face of those who falsely claim to be similar.
The game is Bru...fucking...tal.
Simple graphics, a clear call back to the days of ASCI and it's ilk. Actually very endearing when you get to know the various sprites and what they are/represent.
Incredibly deep character building.
Incredibly Interesting lore.
Oddly endearing sense of humour.
Mixes the old "Roguelike" gameplay loop with a basic survival aspect of hunger and thirst, food can be collected with the right abilties or bought.
Crafting is pretty nifty needing both knowledge, proper character set up, and a good array of materials found in the world or bought.
A lot of features, mechanics, potentially hundreds, if not thousands of character builds.
Procedural generation allows for a hell of a lot of replay ability.
One of those titles that can either be a short and sweet run before work, or a good solid friday night with a can of juice/beer and a load of snacks.

Cons -

Early Access, though proving to be incredibly useful for this game, does mess with saves from time to time.
Brutal learning curve, needs a fair deal of research and patience to actually survive.
A lot of people may be put off by the simplicity of the graphical side.
Not for the impatient or temper prone.
Very, very unforgiving to those who just rush in head first without thought.
Could be considered tedious in terms of the hunger and thirst, as many have and probably will utterly forget that the two exist and can kill you.
Permadeath is a thing (I know a great many folk who utterly hate permadeath, thought it was worth a note).


Tip for newbies- Food can be scarce thanks to RNG. Kill "Glowfish" in the areas surrounding the starting town (Joppa) and pick up their corpses, the more the better, just don't overload your inventory, they are plentiful and food will be less of an issue for you at the begining few areas and levels.

At the time of writing this I haven't played this game long enough to know just how good it is, but I have played enough to realize this is the game is everything I had hoped it would be. While a throwback to the of Rogue days of yore, CoQ builds on the genre in a way that is completely new and surpasses those classics with its depth of writing, sound design, world building, and programming finesse. 
In terms of its early release status, this game is a near-finished product with very active development adding content, balancing, and fixes that amount to, "polish". Don't let that stop you from purchase, as it stands the game is worth every penny.
Apples and oranges, but Dwarf Fortress now has a worthy contender. It's truly exciting to see the ASCII genre being revived with such talent. When graphics are stripped away it's easier to look at a game in terms of writing, mechanics, and code. A programmer myself, I am deeply humbled and intrigued by what is going on here with the NPCs. I don't know if I've been duped by some clever trickery, but I've encountered situations that have simply left me dumbfounded (in a good way). If a tough as nails tactical roguelike with incredibly complicated world building and NPC mechanics sounds fun, go ahead and give it a go, you'll definitely enjoy Caves of Qud.

That being said, I do have one gripe so far. I play with a controller on the couch, get over it devs, we like to do that. I don't mind setting up the mappings, and while it would be nice to see controllers officially supported, there are some fundamental control flaws that make a couch-session near impossible (without a wireless numpad). The key bindings are needlessly convoluted on top of an already complicated game. I won't waste the reader's time getting into specifics so I'll just say this:

Might be the best roguelike I've played. I really love the setting, mechanics, and even the look of the game. While I think there could be some better diversity in equipment, the unique skills and mutations really make combat feel satisfying no matter what you're using. It reminds me quite a bit of Cataclysm: DDA, but with less focus on survival and more on combat and exploration. There aren't very many quests to do currently, but I hope there will be more to come because the ones already implemented are engaging with interesting locations and enemies. Also, this game got me to read A Canticle for Leibowitz, one of the inspirations for the game's setting, which was a great read- and it made me appreciate the game even more in turn.

This game has two huge successes which make it special in my eyes. The first is the combat system, which manages to be fairly deep with plenty of moments where you really have to think smart and plan ahead to survive, while also being simple to pick up. There isn't an overabundance of tools at your disposal like in some other roguelikes, just a good number of useful and flexible skills and items, which helps combat keep its flow. The second strength is the setting, which is a bit harder to explain. It's a type of post-apocalyptic environment which is not normally seen in games, where humanity has regressed so severely thousands of years after the initial disaster that even simple batteries are artifacts of an ancient time that an average person might not even recognize. Like I said, it's a bit hard to put it into writing, but it's such an interesting concept that is so clearly present everywhere in the game that it elevates the entire experience.

I give this game a 10. Yes, it's a 10 while it's in early access, and I hope it gets even better in the future.

The store page's description says pretty much anything I could about what kind of game Caves of Qud is, though I will add in that if you know (or are willing to Google) what Gamma World is, then this is basically [strike]Spaceballs[/strike] Gamma World: The Video Game. I played this game a few years back when it was free and much less complete thanks to a YouTuber called Plumphelmetpunk's videos on it. Loved it then, love it now, and with all of the frequent updates, it keeps getting better every time I play it.

On to gameplay. Although Caves of Qud is extremely well-made, at it's heart it's still a fairly normal roguelike. You make, you die, you learn. You make better, you live longer, you die anyway, you learn some more. Repeat until tired of game, either due to frustration or total mastery. There's a lot of different options and a ton of fun and viable builds to play with, so you'll have a hard time running out of ways to die horribly. The main thing that sets it apart is the world, which is apparently retrofuturist, but most people will just call it post-apocalyptic and call it a day. There's a lot to do and see out there, but unfortunately most of it is obsfucated behind a pile of purposefully obscure words. Mostly QoC just does it in an attempt to make the world sound as exotic as possible, but there's only so many $5 words one person can handle before you just start glazing over the descriptions.

tl;dr - It's an amazingly good roguelike if you like roguelikes. The world is unique and interesting. Bring a dictionary unless you tend to use words like "tumescent" in everyday conversations.

29527050.review:
The game is set in what can be seen as a post-apocalyptic wasteland with mutants, espers, ancient ruins, and a persistent scarcity of water—so scarce, in fact, that it's the default form of currency in the pseudo-barter economy that the whole world has adopted. Honestly speaking, CoQ is better enjoyed when you have time to sit down and immerse yourself, as opposed to favoring the pick-up-and-play nature of many other roguelikes and roguelites. If that sounds like your cup of tea, definitely give this a shot.

Caves of Qud is a roguelike that brings something fresh to the genre, not in its entirety, but in enough ways that I feel it's worth highlighting if you're tired of the same-old Nethack and ADOM experiences. Your direction is not given through narrative exposition, but rather by talking to people and forming your own understanding of what's going on in the world, with the choice of how best to proceed being left entirely up to you. This particular aspect of the gameplay isn't original, but the setting and lore behind the realm you're thrust into definitely is.

The style of the game aside, the controls deserve being commented on due to how much they affect the enjoyability of the game. They're a mix of old and new that most RL veterans will appreciate. It's not quite as modernized as something like Tales of Maj'Eyal, but has enough improvements over the retro fare to be appreciable and praise-worthy. The controls may take some getting used to for those new to the genre, but are otherwise standard fare, with some level of customizability allowing for streamlining use of abilities and talents. It's even possible (using Joy2Key) to map most standard actions to a controller and play the game almost entirely through that, which is something that very few true roguelikes allow for. This is just a quality-of-life thing, but it's a huge one, and one that makes CoQ a perfect intermediary even for people looking to dip their toes in the waters of more complex RL titles. In short, the controls are varied enough to require some minor memorization, but simple and intuitive enough that picking up the many controls doesn't take much time at all.

Last, but definitely not least, is the gameplay itself. God damn does this thing deliver on what makes a great roguelike great: options. This may be best expressed by recounting my initial experiences with the game, as compared to my current one:

My first character was a multi-legged, winged chimera Gunslinger who I intended to be the fastest gunner the game world had ever seen. I took traits to make him faster than almost anything I could run into, gave him the ability to see in the dark, and specced to prep myself for sniping my foes with impunity. He lost his life to thirst, as I had no idea that you could harvest any one of the thousands of vines surrounding the common salt-water pools in the world for an abundant source of fresh water. I made the mistake of using my sole fresh water container to scoop up salt water, intending to attempt to purify it using fire. Not only did that prove not possible (to my knowledge), but I was soon parched and without water to afford... well... water.

Lesson learned: Harvest water from watervines, and treat the liquid as an emergency reserve.

My second character, along with the three or so after him, were all re-attempts of the same initial Gunslinger. This time, I made it to the end of the first 'dungeon', accomplished my mission, and as I was preparing to leave, noticed a massive sleeping mutant Bearling in a corner. I was careful, inspecting it from a distance and assessing that it was far too risky to attempt to wake it. As my luck would have it, a bat in the same room as the Bearling—friendly towards me due to my wings improving my reputation with winged creatures—decided to 'help' me by attacking and waking the hibernating beast. Within the span of two turns, the bat was eviscerated and the bear had charged directly to me, its lunging bite taking me from full life to the game-over screen all at once.

Lesson learned: Pay attention not only to Hostile threats, but even to the supposed allies that might cause me trouble indirectly.

In his next life, my Gunslinger made it much farther along than before, making it to the fourth in-game story location which had me searching an underground complex full of hostile mechs for an important NPC. I noticed an armed turret through a doorway. As I had faced two at once before and survived, I made the mistake of being cocky, thinking I could just walk up to it and melee it to death, as I was low on ammo but too stubborn to retreat to restock. The instant I stepped in the room, I got flashbacks to that one room in Dark Souls 2 with all the ballistas being aimed at the sole entrance; no less than four turrets beeped as they locked onto me. I did the only thing I could, taking a step back to break line of sight, but it was already too late.

Lesson learned: Approach all situations with caution unless completely equipped to handle their potential outcomes.

After a few games like the ones described above, in most cases involving me resorting to killing things with melee weapons as a range-specialized wandered due the combined factors of a scarcity of ammo and my own terrible aim, I decided to try a psychic character instead. This went much smoother early on, as I was able to blast my enemies away using lasers without worry for ammo or missing my targets. However, I was much more fragile in return for my power. This character did not die to thirst, bear, or turret. He died at the end of the first dungeon, 5XP away from his next level, having attempted to gain this experience by attacking a thorny vine on the wall, becoming stuck on said thorns, and subsequently bleeding to death as he tried in vain to pull himself away while the plant lashed out at him in self-defense. If I had simply used my laser on the plant instead of trying to melee it to death, this particularly humiliating but well-deserved death would never have taken place.

Lesson learned: Don't panic. When in danger, stop to consider what tools are available and how best to apply them.

As it stands, I've learned from my many mistakes, and my current character is doing quite well. This learning experience is a huge part of the game though, as the world will not hesitate to beat the player down at every opportunity presented. My advice to those of you who read about these experiences and were enticed by the prospect of a difficult and punishing game would be to read up on the game before-hand, learn what messages mean what, and equip themselves with the knowledge to see themselves towards a successful completion of CoQ. Avoid spoilers where possible when doing so, but absolutely attempt to find logs of other players' mistakes and their consequences so that you can avoid making them yourself. In my case, this kind of involving experience is exactly what I look for in my roguelike titles, and I whole-heartedly recommend this game for it.

29455422.review:
Caves of Qud is in Early Access, but don't let that stop you; new features are being added (almost) every Friday.  As of the writing of this review, the most recent updates have revamped Long Blades and Axe skill trees, which had drawn the community's ire for being underpowered.  But enough about that, let's get to the game itself.

Qud is a post-apocalyptic world rife with technology from the old days just waiting to be discovered.  The game is a good old-fashioned roguelike set in this world, offering tons of character customization.  As in most roguelikes, the action takes place on a grid of tiles, operating by turn-based rules, so the enemy only acts when you do, offering unlimited time to plan your approach.  Many sights and interactions are conveyed entirely through text, thankfully very well-written in Caves of Qud's case.  In fact, it's this writing, the setting itself, that makes CoQ stand apart from the rest of the roguelikes.

For example, due to the massive amounts of salt covering the planet, fresh water is such a scarcity that it is actually the game's currency!  As in most roguelikes, your character has hunger and thirst to manage, but water weighs quite a lot, and merchants will take it from you if you can't pony up valuable enough goods for a trade.  Do you hoard water to stay healthy, trade it away for that sweet dagger, or get yourself a gold nugget that weighs very little and (unlike other items) always sells for 100% of its value?  It's a balance of risk and reward unlike anything I've ever seen.

Also, the game's "faction" system can ensure even more variability than most roguelikes.  Nearly every sentient race keeps track of your actioins and allies, and responds accordingly.  One notable instance of this is the Machinimists, who revere the ancient artifacts as holy relics, even the lowly folding metal chair.  One quest in the main story involves entering one of their most revered holy grounds.  Most characters will have to fight their way in, but those closely allied with the Machinimists can simply walk in.  And again, it's not just the Machinimists...you may find yourself allied with birds, the Putus Templar, fungi...and your allies will not attack you, or may even help if they see you fighting someone.

There is a main quest line in the game even in this version, but it's relatively short.  Fortunately, the "Sultans of Qud" update added randomly generated history to the game.  With this history of Qud's ancient rulers comes ruins of shrines, arenas, and more dedicated to them.  By studying engravings and statues around the world, you may gain a lead that points you to a historic site, within which a powerful item lies in wait, one wielded by the sultan themselves.  The explorable world is huge, stretching far and wide as well as deep underground.  Even in the game's current state, there's plenty to do.

But the star of the show here is the customization.  Tons of mutations, powers, skill trees, and equipment ensure that you can play this game however you want.  Be a four-armed porcupine and wield four pistols!  Shoot fire from your mind and electricity from your hands!  Chop off your enemy's face with an axe, then wear it!  Psychically beguile a goat, then proselytize to a lowly farmer, thus traveling with a party of three (who themselves can level up and develop mutations)!  Learn to build and modify machinery, to arm yourself with a stun rod and grenades!  Pull off some sweet angel cosplay with a flaming sword and beautiful wings!  If mutations aren't your thing, staying "pure" grants you access to cybernetic implants, including a railgun!  Or attach robotic arms to yourself and put shields on them, and whip out your best Sundowner impersonation!

Overall, Caves of Qud is a fantastic roguelike that compares favorably to even some of the greats of the genre, and this is in its current Early Access form.  Once more quests are added and the game is released proper, be prepared to see this on a lot of people's best-of lists.

Caves of Qud is a brilliant game, and is the title that finally hooked me into actual turn-based roguelikes as a genre. Up to now, I've loved rogueLITES (things like Nuclear Throne, Binding of Isaac, and Enter the Gungeon) but rogueLIKES themselves haven't ever been something I could stick with, for whatever reason.

Enter Caves of Qud - a game with a fantastically unique setting, surprisingly easy to learn UI, and some of the best character creation/customization I've ever encountered. Seriously - I'm a guy who loves tinkering with builds, and the mutation system is CoQ is second to none in terms of offering unique and varied playstyles and various options to try out.

True, it's still not the MOST accessible game (you'll almost definitely need Google open on another screen to cross-reference how mechanics work) but you can learn the game in short order, and the Guides section here on Steam has some phenomenal work. I can also speak to the developer and the community's credit - every time I've had a question, it's been answered very promptly on the Discussions board. The game also offers a host of (completely optional, off by default) debug options, including the ability to disable perma-death if you'd like. This is great for people new to roguelikes in general, and who want to get a stronger grasp on Qud's mechanics and learn its ins-and-outs with some training wheels on.

I generally have a rule with any early access game - to justify a purchase, it has to be worth it if the devs stop updating it as soon as it's added to my cart. Qud absolutely qualifies - the game is wonderful in its current state, and seems to be getting regular updates, which is phenomenal. The dev has also promised to release a road map this year on what we can expect leading up to release, which is a level of transparency I very much appreciate.

All in all, I can't recommend this title enough, ESPECIALLY with it still being early access. Live and drink, friends.

If Caves of Qud was merely a standout roguelike dungeon crawler with clockwork-tight mechanics and a refreshingly accessible UI, it would be deserving of perhaps 20 of the hours I've put into it. It is the writing, the prose within the description of seemingly ordinary items, that has me returning for the additional 200+ hours I have logged.

Qud is an alien world that flourishes with life among the ruins of the old, technologically advanced world, evoking images of towering chrome skyscrapers choked with vines and vast caverns echoing with the sounds of dripping water. The skill system combined with a vast array of mutation options means that no two characters play the same way, and the recent Sultans of Qud update adds procedurally-generated histories (with corresponding ruins and artifacts) to a world already packed to the secondary gills with lore and treasures to uncover.

Caves of Qud is a masterclass in worldbuilding, and in it's best moments evokes the strange beauty of a Frazetta or Brom painting without feeling derivative. I cannot recommend this game enough.

29215869.review:
Caves of Qud is a roguelike that combines traditional elements of the genre with a fully realized post-post-apocalyptic world in the most wonderful ways. You'll find artifacts of the previous civilization hinting at the world they lived in while fighting off mutant hyenamen, cultists who worship the sultans of yore, and horrific wildlife. Each tile of the world map is explorable and contains a nearly infinite dungeon as well as numerous ruins of historical significance potentially containing great treasures. 

The as yet unfinished main storyline will take you from the humble caverns of Red Rock to the cesspits of Golgotha, and eventually to the freezing depths of Bethesda Susa, which is as far as I've been able to survive so far. Even unfinished Qud paints vivid imagery in your mind as you begin to understand how the world functions. The technology of the world stretches from simple swords and shields to powerful cybernetics and energy weapons. 

As far as character building goes, you can choose to be a mutant with a variety of mutations and defects or a true human from one of the last surviving eco-domes. Humans learn skills faster and start with some gear, but mutants grow in power and number of mutations as you level. The mutations you have range from the physical, like extra limbs or a tough carapace, to the purely mental like conjuring forcefields or directly attacking enemies' minds with your own. There's an innumerous variety of builds once you factor in mutations, caste, and background. 

Caves of Qud is like if you put ADOM, D___RL, Dwarf Fortress, and Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup in a blender and let the densest juices from each fill your glass. If you know what any of these games are, Qud is definitely for you.

29016554.review:
Caves of Qud is a roguelike that brings something fresh to the genre, not in its entirety, but in enough ways that I feel it's worth highlighting if you're tired of the same-old Nethack and ADOM experiences. Your direction is not given through narrative exposition, but rather by talking to people and forming your own understanding of what's going on in the world, with the choice of how best to proceed being left entirely up to you. This particular aspect of the gameplay isn't original, but the setting and lore behind the realm you're thrust into definitely is.

The game is set in what can be seen as a post-apocalyptic wasteland with mutants, espers, ancient ruins, and a persistent scarcity of water—so scarce, in fact, that it's the default form of currency in the pseudo-barter economy that the whole world has adopted. Honestly speaking, CoQ is better enjoyed when you have time to sit down and immerse yourself, as opposed to favoring the pick-up-and-play nature of many other roguelikes and roguelites. If that sounds like your cup of tea, definitely give this a shot.

The style of the game aside, the controls deserve being commented on due to how much they affect the enjoyability of the game. They're a mix of old and new that most RL veterans will appreciate. It's not quite as modernized as something like Tales of Maj'Eyal, but has enough improvements over the retro fare to be appreciable and praise-worthy. The controls may take some getting used to for those new to the genre, but are otherwise standard fare, with some level of customizability allowing for streamlining use of abilities and talents. It's even possible (using Joy2Key) to map most standard actions to a controller and play the game almost entirely through that, which is something that very few true roguelikes allow for. This is just a quality-of-life thing, but it's a huge one, and one that makes CoQ a perfect intermediary even for people looking to dip their toes in the waters of more complex RL titles. In short, the controls are varied enough to require some minor memorization, but simple and intuitive enough that picking up the many controls doesn't take much time at all.

Last, but definitely not least, is the gameplay itself. God damn does this thing deliver on what makes a great roguelike great: options. This may be best expressed by recounting my initial experiences with the game, as compared to my current one:

[list]
[*] My first character was a multi-legged, winged chimera Gunslinger who I intended to be the fastest gunner the game world had ever seen. I took traits to make him faster than almost anything I could run into, gave him the ability to see in the dark, and specced to prep myself for sniping my foes with impunity. He lost his life to thirst, as I had no idea that you could harvest any one of the thousands of vines surrounding the common salt-water pools in the world for an abundant source of fresh water. I made the mistake of using my sole fresh water container to scoop up salt water, intending to attempt to purify it using fire. Not only did that prove not possible (to my knowledge), but I was soon parched and without water to afford... well... water.

Lesson learned: Harvest water from watervines, and treat the liquid as an emergency reserve.

[*] My second character, along with the three or so after him, were all re-attempts of the same initial Gunslinger. This time, I made it to the end of the first 'dungeon', accomplished my mission, and as I was preparing to leave, noticed a massive sleeping mutant Bearling in a corner. I was careful, inspecting it from a distance and assessing that it was far too risky to attempt to wake it. As my luck would have it, a bat in the same room as the Bearling—friendly towards me due to my wings improving my reputation with winged creatures—decided to 'help' me by attacking and waking the hibernating beast. Within the span of two turns, the bat was eviscerated and the bear had charged directly to me, its lunging bite taking me from full life to the game-over screen all at once.

Lesson learned: Pay attention not only to Hostile threats, but even to the supposed allies that might cause me trouble indirectly.

[*] In his next life, my Gunslinger made it much farther along than before, making it to the fourth in-game story location which had me searching an underground complex full of hostile mechs for an important NPC. I noticed an armed turret through a doorway. As I had faced two at once before and survived, I made the mistake of being cocky, thinking I could just walk up to it and melee it to death, as I was low on ammo but too stubborn to retreat to restock. The instant I stepped in the room, I got flashbacks to that one room in Dark Souls 2 with all the ballistas being aimed at the sole entrance; no less than four turrets beeped as they locked onto me. I did the only thing I could, taking a step back to break line of sight, but it was already too late.

Lesson learned: Approach all situations with caution unless completely equipped to handle their potential outcomes.

[*] After a few games like the ones described above, in most cases involving me resorting to killing things with melee weapons as a range-specialized wandered due the combined factors of a scarcity of ammo and my own terrible aim, I decided to try a psychic character instead. This went much smoother early on, as I was able to blast my enemies away using lasers without worry for ammo or missing my targets. However, I was much more fragile in return for my power. This character did not die to thirst, bear, or turret. He died at the end of the first dungeon, 5XP away from his next level, having attempted to gain this experience by attacking a thorny vine on the wall, becoming stuck on said thorns, and subsequently bleeding to death as he tried in vain to pull himself away while the plant lashed out at him in self-defense. If I had simply used my laser on the plant instead of trying to melee it to death, this particularly humiliating but well-deserved death would never have taken place.

Lesson learned: Don't panic. When in danger, stop to consider what tools are available and how best to apply them.
[/list]

As it stands, I've learned from my many mistakes, and my current character is doing quite well. This learning experience is a huge part of the game though, as the world will not hesitate to beat the player down at every opportunity presented. My advice to those of you who read about these experiences and were enticed by the prospect of a difficult and punishing game would be to read up on the game before-hand, learn what messages mean what, and equip themselves with the knowledge to see themselves towards a successful completion of CoQ. Avoid spoilers where possible when doing so, but absolutely attempt to find logs of other players' mistakes and their consequences so that you can avoid making them yourself. In my case, this kind of involving experience is exactly what I look for in my roguelike titles, and I whole-heartedly recommend this game for it.

28840553.review:
If you're expecting a hand-holding first quest to gently bop five harmless creatures and collect their fur, put on a solid helmet and buckle its chinstrap.  Caves of Qud throws you right into the deep end of a mutant sci-fi/fantasy mashup with barbarians, manimals, swordsmen, and a dizzying variety of flora & fauna.

The steep, almost punishing learning curve is par for the course in good rogue-likes, and so arriving in Joppa with NO IDEA of what button to press is a sign -- to veterans of Nethack and Dwarf Fortress -- that a great deal of fun is imminent.  Statting out your character seems easy enough, but the massive variety of options (mutations, backgrounds, tribes) seem to offer hundreds of ways to try to impose your will on the world.  There are excellent help menus, very good context UI, and warnings when you're about to do something stupid (like steal) to help get you up that first vertical surface, though.  Patience, attentive reading, and good note-taking can speed you along.

The graphics have recently improved from colorful ASCII to lo-res sprites. The aesthetic resembles some of the tilesets ou might see in Dwarf Fortress.  

The questing & reputation systems are more complete than DF Adventurer Mode, with Mehmet and Argyve giving you quests that skip right over "kill ten toothless rats" and jump straight into "suicidal raid on a nearby hostile zone".  If you can put in the effort to learn the systems and survive the first quests you'll be well on your way toward leveling up a powerful adventurer.  

Great for fans of procedural roguelikes, but expect to work hard for the rewards it offers.

28783158.review:
Now THIS is a rogue-like. You ever find yourself going through the tag, looking at all the crazy stuff people throw the name rogue-like onto? Have you ever PLAYED the original Rogue? If you haven't, I recomend you do that, its a fun little game for the most part. Once you've done that, you probably have a pretty good idea of what Caves of Qud has to offer. At least, in its most basic form.

Now imagine if Adventure Mode of Dwarf Fortress had a baby with a post-apocalyptic fiction author's imagination. Combine that with the original concept of the original Rogue, and you more or less have Caves of Qud.

Now, my first experience with Qud wasn't that great. I couldn't figure out how to do anything. Turns out, I wasn't really trying hard enough. The key mapping is right there in the Esc menu.

So, Caves of Qud. It's a hard game. Extremely hard? Well, maybe, but definitely hard. It takes a little while to get used to, a little thinking to understand, and a lot of patience and perseverance to really get into the game. It's difficulty will be both a turn on and a turn off, it just depends on who you are as a "gamer", and you should know by now what type of games you enjoy, especially if you're looking at a review for a bona fide rogue-like made with ASCII graphics.

The atmosphere is amazing. The setting is amazing. The gameplay is fun and satisfying. The story it tells is interesting. The character creation is detailed and full of interesting ideas. 

In the end, what it all comes down to is this; Do you want a real rogue-like? Do you want to recapture that feeling of exploration and wonder that so many games these days are missing? Do you want to die? A lot? Do you want to be rewarded for your hard work? If the answer to any of these questions was yes, then this is the game for you. If you answered no to any but the second question, you probably shouldnt buy this game. Personally, though, I definitely recommend it.
