28103581.review:
I will start this review by stating that I am not a die-hard "Roguelike" player. I haven't played any of the classics except for Tales of Maj'eyal and wouldnt consider myself particularly knoweldgeable about the genre history and so on. With that said I consider Caves of Qud to be one of the, if not, the best game I have purchased and played in 2016.

The first time I heard about this game was on a forum where it was described as retrofuturistic and inspired by post-post apocalyptic fiction. I was intrigued by talk of sentient plants and also a procedurally generated game with more of a focus on a narrative. My expectations were not only met, but were blown away when I finally decided to play the game. 

Caves of Qud is hard to describe. Its often comically stupid, full of crazy situations and at the same time solumn and steeped with a history that is intruging and suprisingly deep. Its a world where not much is explained because to explain it would be convoluted, why does a machingun turret worship a god or why are there mutant hyena people living in something called the rust wells? It is a testament to the vision and world the developers have created that something as absurd as a techno-cyborg-bear can not only exist , but actually feels coherant within the setting. 

The asthetic choices made in the game also really resonated with me and the ascii / pixel art is superb and full of character, helped by an excellent choice of colour pallet. There are also stylistic flourishes that one wouldn't expect in a game with such simple graphics such as floating text highlighting things happening around you and clever ways of giving items in your inventory more character, despite the text based nature (one that comes to mind is discovering a jewel encrusted item with all the characters in its name coloured differently to represent gems). I would say the sound is quite bare-bones at the moment, but the music and sound effects that are present are good, the music in particular is very evocative and used to excellent effect at special locations (specifically the 6th Day Stilt). 

As a game to play CoQ is full of variety, it has a really robust character building system. Essentially you pick between a mutant or a pure-blooded "True-kin". The mutants get to pick between 20 or so "powers" which could be something like shooting flames from your hands or a physical abberation like having two heads. The true-kin can subdue robots and have slightly better base attributes. Mutants pick a background such as marauder or nomad and then True-kin pick which Arcology they hail from. These serve to augment your stats and give different equipment to begin. Both then pick from many skill trees thoughout the game as they level up. Each game you start in the same village, Joppa, and begin the quest anew. You will die and die often, each time you reincarnate to do it again. The world is static, but aside from some plot critical locations each area is randomly generated each time. Each game is familiar, but always different, every character I have created has been memorable in his own way.

The game can feel punishingly hard and unforgiving. Deaths can feel cheap and unfair. Sometimes they are, but it is still in early access.  There are some character builds that work incredibly well, some feel like you are just hindering yourself. Some stats feel useless (willpower) and others too strong (Agility). I personally like the unbalanced aspects, but I can imagine somepeople being upset over the death of a long lived character. I have never made it to the end of the game, in fact I have no idea if there is an end as yet. I can't get enough of it regardless. The developers are very communicative and updates happen frequently. I wouldn't have been dissapointed if I had bought this product as a fully released title, its that good. I have no doubt this game will go from stregnth to stregnth as its development continues. I cannot reccommend it enough.

28096056.review:
[h1]One of the oddest roguelikes out there and it's only growing to be odder.[/h1]

Form the miljeu of the game I have only to say that its a medievalish society set aeons after an end of the advanced civilizations. Were bronze sword wielding barbarians are gunned down by rustcovered walking missile platforms and floating indestructible laser pyramids. Most of the inhabitants of qud care or know of the ancient world as much as you care or know about the history of pre summerian tribes. The world has moved on.

Apart of the world map obiviously showing the ruins of an overgrown city on a coast of a long since tried sea, the postapocalyptic elemenst of this world are often unobivious. The remains of old world lurk in the details as an almost sinster force. The call of adventure is carried on ever transmitting signal captured by an weird inventor in the marshlands. The chaotic disase ridden dungeon is filled with coveyor belts, burners and haywire waste mangement robots.  The ice dungeon an cryogenic medical facilty. Magical talking stones hyper advanced computers.  The ancient fortresses remains of once urban constructions, the greates of kings lives in a tower that elevates to the very orbit.

Soon after the tables turn, instead of what you can recognise under all the ther salt, rust and slime it's the unrecogizable that turns eerie. Out on the saltbeds church has been build on gigantic skeleton of what excatly? One of the oldest factions on Qud are conglomerate of sentient plants? Who were the Eaters of the Earth? Why most of the books read as weird streams of consioucness? Nightmarish space demons and chrome angels or degenerate bioweapons and malfuctioning robots? Holy artifact or ray gun?
What occured naturaly and what was once made?


[h1]About gameplay[/h1]

Next to Nethack and IVAN this is the roguelike I have played most and to other games in the genere and especialy compared to the Nethack this is much more pleasant to play.

First of all: there is option to disable premadeath as well as an option to enable free saving and loading of the game!

Menus operate as you would expect from a proper computer RPG and while they are sometimes when you need to use letters to pick items you want, for most of the time every thing can be handled with numpad, space and enter.
As writing of this mouse based interface is being implemented and is already working for the game it self, but not yet for all menu screens.  Personaly I prefer the keyboard controls, here is why:

The controls are nothing like the usual RL "command for every leter on the keyboard both lower and upper case".
There is one contex sensitive action key (defaults to space) that automaticly does what ever is most appropriate to do to the cell you stand in or the ones nearby, from talking to opening/closing doors and picking up items or filling your water skin. Spesific keys for all those actions do exists for the rare cases that the contex sensitive action gets confused, but I for example have no clue what the spesific key to start a conversation is and I doubt that I never need to learn that.

Another quality of life feature is automatic exploration to quickly map out screens. Related to that is the fact when pressing + or - to go up or down stairs the character atuomaticly heads to closest seen stairs, while this doesn't work if the stairs are not on the same screen it still makes returning form your deep earth spelunking trough already cleared out cave levels much faster.

Moving on from controls to gameplay itself, the CoQ has a shortage of Nethacks trademark "Yet Another Stupid Deaths".
The command look will always tell you how dangerous the creature you are looking at is compared to you and wether or not is aggressive. You can also always see what said creature is equipped with. Even though you might not know what item you are excatly looking at, in a world where "Unknow artifacts" wielded by hostile mutants are at best grenades and rocket launchers at worst, you know to be cautious.

Corpses do not rot and very few have any effects other than their varying nutritional value.
Like wise there are no 'cursed' items even when items have negative efffects they are told on the items description.
Fidling with an unknow artifact with an character who has a low inteligence will at worst break the said item, meaning that you have to pay for tinker to get it repaired and identified.

There are diseases and infections you can catch and neither are trivial to get rid off. The cures are randomly genereated per character and may cause you some trouble. Though you never know, you may actualy be better off with your new spreading mushroom symbiote infection pals than you were alone.

There are two ways to gain followers one reguires a spesific mental beguiling mutation and other an ability to proselytize, both also need a character with a high ego score. Both methods are limited to one follower so two at max (barring some strange later game occurences like clones). So team based rpg this is not.

Combat is straight forward and rather simple.
Use melee, abilities, fire arms, mutations, throwing weapons and sprint away if your opponent hits harder than you. Effects like stun, bleed and dismemberment of limbs are spesific skills and often limited to certain types of weapons (short blades, long blades, axes and cudgels). Weapons differ with their armor piercing and damage roll numbers, bonus changes to said bleed and dismemberment chances and rarely with extra damage as burning, freezing or electrocuting.
So fancy damage simulations and injury systems this game doesn't have either.

Unusualy for RLs Caves of Qud models temperatures much better than you would even notice at first glance. Any ongoing fires rise the ambient temperature and spamming pyrokinesis and or spraying all over with flamethrower you will son find out that everything in game has an iginition temperature and in worst case scenario an accidently ignited pond of asphalt will skyrocket the ambient temperature causing everything on screen to burst in flames. Hot steam from boiling water has to be one of the most humilating ways to die in this game.
Having a go playing with a mutant build with both cryokinesis and pyrokinesis mutations allows you to get most out of this simulation.

Typical for roguelike games, there is much to do in game and trying out different character builds and mutations will keep you interested for a long time.

That said the game is still a work in progress. Main quest isn't finished yet and side quests are rather few.
The updates have been weekly ever since from the steam release. If you are interested at it's very much good to buy in it's current state with no gratingly missing features or bugs.

This is a great roguelike, mixing a sprinkling of plot and story into an open world full of shenanigans, exploration, and violent death.

I am cutting and freezing my way through the post-apocalyptic mushroom jungle wearing my clone's face, on a quest from a race of subterranean albino ape technologists, feeling like a powerful mutant warrior wielding a surreptitiously acquired fist of the ape god. Then I suddenly come upon a group of sludge-beings that spontaneously evolve from primordial goo and lava and who are just barely able to collectively melt me to nothingness despite my psychically boosted toughness, sleeping gas spraying out and a clutch of grenades. Of course this is all typical in Qud.
Pros: huge game world, intuitive UI, incredibly unique and deep setting w/ lore contained in books, characters, descriptions and the physical environment (and the philosophy references e.g. to the logic of Russell and to Socrates are awesome for someone who knows any philosophy), huge amount of ability to customize character both at start of game and throughout play, huge amount of player agency (as there should be in any proper roguelike, but this world and its emergent gameplay feels more natural than e.g. ADOM, which I also enjoy but no where near as much as Qud), beautiful graphics (for me anyway), really truly great music (please more!), new features and bugs squashed every week, optional permadeath and saving/loading, dynamic faction allegiances, infectious diseases with procedurally generated cures, tons of items to craft and various ways to modify gear, cybernetic implants, and I'm sure a million other things I'm forgetting
Cons: main quest is not yet finished, and after countless hours in Qud starting a new character in Joppa for the umpteenth time feels a bit tedious (but still worth it)
Overall: game is amazing, up there for me with classics like Fallout 1/2, ADOM, Darklands, Ultima Underworld. If the game continues to develop to completion I'm sure it will be considered one of the all-time great RPGs by those with refined taste.

[h1]Main review / impressions:[/h1]

I...... Cannot really recommend this. Which is a surprise, to myself.

I've played a good deal of MUDs and Rogue-likes (actual Rogue-likes, as in not just procedural/random generation and permadeath games), lately I've spent an embarrassing amount of time playing Cataclysm: Dark Days Ahead (Which is free, by the way!). I've also played NetHack, and an assortment of other similar games. And I find them thoroughly compelling.

And this was just not very compelling. Does it look slightly fancier? Sure, yes. The animated sprites intermixed with the "tiles" does look genuinely neat - I applaud that. I'm not stuck-up about "Rogue-aesthetics". Turning off the tiles for an "ascii mode" is silly and looks bad, this is not a terminal window, and it shows. But that's not really a problem, just leave the tiles on.


However, the actual interface is .... Well, it's a lot of not-good.

[olist]
[*]The interface is massive in scale. Huge. Enormous. Galactic. It covers, literally, a third of the screen. Even at 2560x1440 screen res. And it OVERLAYS the game world! It doesn't off-set it, or attempts to scale the world window in any way, no, 1/3rd of the world is at all times covered by a massive UI unless you hide the UI.. And now you have no UI! Wow. I thought we figured this out 2 decades ago? Especially now in the world of non-Square aspect ratio displays! You have room for a side-bar plus a perfectly square game world, it's perfect! Use it!
[*]The text log is also massive, and it's so massive that it becomes unreadable. A mere 2 or 3 events taking place, even if each event is only 4 or 5 words long, forces it to split the sentence and scroll, making you miss a majority of what actually happened, not to mention having no sense of flow of events (you can't, at a glance, see a few turns into the past... Often you cannot even see ONE turn into the past!). Although there is a smaller text log too in another corner, but it's so inconspicuous that I didn't even see it for an hour. And then I promptly forgot about it again. Also, that hardly solves the problem, I don't want two text logs on my screen, taking up even MORE of that screen space.
[*]The interfaces that you use the most, such as inventory and other screens, are OK to navigate, with very Roguelike hotkeys as well as Numpad navigation which is always groovy to see, but they are, again, absolutely massive in scale. Very few menu items fit per screen, and on my 1440p screen, a single letter is literally larger than my thumb. You could fit every interface panel in the game on 1 screen if scaled to a sensible size... Obviously not true for smaller screens, and not a practical solution, but seriously, goddamn, the UI is so large. It's humongous. Vast. Gigantic. Colossal. It is, in fact, super-colossal.
[/olist]

So, the user interface aside, and I have to point out that it's quite hard to do worse, UI-wise, than a terminal-based Roguelike. Even games that have it down to a T, like Cataclysm DDA, are sorta clumsy and unintuitive. This is worse. Despite being a Unity game, not a literal Windows CMD or linux Terminal window.


Alright, so what about the game? I don't know about the game... I could not give it an honest try. In a game like this, the user interface IS the game, to a large extent. I don't doubt that it can generate interesting worlds and all that jazz. But it's too clunky, and feels too ... flat? Not flat in terms of elevation, just ... flat in terms of character. The fake scan-lines are cute for about 10 seconds, but says a lot about the intent of the game - the intent is to [i]pretend to be[/i] a terminal-type oldschool game (by the way, no PC monitor ever had scanlines like that, ever. I owned many - they're clear and clean like an LCD).  It does a lot to force this upon the player - it beats you over the head with a giant club, saying I AM SO RETRO WOW HAVE YOU NOTICED IT YET SO RETRO.

That's funny sometimes, and some games take the whole "play pretend retro" theme and run with it, and succeed gloriously at it, or for that matter some games just choose to go very low-fi because they wish to, because they like to, because it lets them focus on other things, and it's fine. But here, there's just nothing to back that up. It's just a generic Roguelike (nothing wrong with that), trying to .. pretend.. like.. it's a generic roguelike? Like, I don't even.... There's some disconnect somewhere. Do tiles, or don't. Don't make tiles made out of ASCII characters. Yeah, sure, they can be minimalist and tile-esque, that's cute, I liked that part, but please, skip the silly parts. Make it a -good- minimalist theme instead, people will have much fonder memories of that.

Anyhow. I found this a frustrating experience. I'll go back to CDDA or NetHack or any other of the dozens of very well made, and free (not that I care, particularly), Rogue-Likes around.



[h1]Now, for those who enjoy ranting and philosophical ramblings:[/h1]


I wished it had been a better experience.

Because; we need these games to exist in a more commercial sense - we need them on Steam, we need them to be developed by paid and excited full-time developers, so that the genre remains healthy and heck even allow the genre to advance in some areas, because there's room for that. Cataclysm is proving it with a incomprehensibly advanced world simulation, Dwarf Fortress is proving that you can generate amazing and complex and deep worlds... NetHack is being the conservative master of the classic, it does classic better than classic itself. So clearly, there's plenty to sink your teeth into if you're making a real Rogue-like in 2016 (or whatever year). Maybe Caves of Qud wanted to be the Roguelike that improved the user experience by NOT being a terminal-type game, by having a more understandable and friendly UI. But this isn't it. It's made in Unity, so clearly they can do this. In fact, as a Unity developer myself, it's evident that the amount of work put into TRYING TO BE a terminal application, must have been quite significant - rather than making an original, thought-out and friendly UI.


I hope this does well, and I hope I'm just a stingy old fart who can't appreciate it. Best wishes to the developers, I hope you find your niche and that the game works out. I hope you can finish your game, we sorely need a Roguelike that is actually complete, rather than stuck in Pre-Alpha/Alpha for the rest of our natural lives. We really do!

Great roguelike! It fits the classic roguelike style in a lot of ways, but it definitely has it's own feel. The early game difficulty seems to vary, but I hear it gets extremely hard later on.

I have no idea how it would be received by a non roguelike player, as I've been playing ascii roguelikes for years, but the controls and menus are definitely more stream-lined than dcss/adom/etc. It's EA, so a lot of these elements are still being worked on and improved.

--------------------------

For roguelike players, I really feel like this game truly has a unique feel, so it's hard to explain. I'll try to relate examples I'm familiar with that express the 'feel' of the game.

It has the big open overmap style of ADOM, where you can really go wherever you want (and probably die). From the big overmap squares you can 'enter' the ground level and travel in normal turns. It's far from complicated Nethack in gameplay, but it's not quite as simplified as DCSS.

There are a lot of interactions, here's a fairly strong example; you have containers you use for carrying water for drinking and trading. But there are other uses, if you are on fire, you can pour water on yourself to put it out, you can make puddles on the ground, drop bloody weapons into them to wash it off. You can gather pretty much any liquid, afaik, including slime, tar, and use it as a (fairly ineffective, in my experience :p) trap. You can even gather blood, for whatever reason. All of these fluids you can pour on the ground, you can drink them and see what happens, you can pour them on yourself. There's a lot of fun experimenting. But I wouldn't say the item interactions are to the complex level of Nethack.

Most of the time when you are actually exploring the world or dungeons, it's more about you using your skills and mutations effectively, or running/using consumables when you're in over your head. But you won't have huge stacks of teleport scrolls or haste potions or anything like that. It's pretty common to see a really strong monster even when you're just lvl 2. You will need to use the sprint skill. Your build and play style is heavily dependant on your mutations/skills. Character building is huge. So far I haven't found any 'get out of jail free card's, like ?tele, in this game (besides the all powerful sprint skill, and some really powerful mental mutations).

Because of the fact that there's no 'clock', you are free to progress as fast as you want. Food and water is easy to get.

There's no cursed items, and the ID game is for a subset of items called artifacts (that end up being various things, like grenades, chairs, weapons) and consists of paying someone to ID it for you, or getting the intelligence/skills to id them yourself.

--------------------------

The free, outdated ascii version gives a bit of insight as to whether you might like the game, but the steam version has come a very long way; I didn't get hooked on the older version nearly as much as I have the new one.

It's EA. So far, I found one bug that caused me to lose data until my last save (that was promptly fixed about twenty minutes later, but still, save often, and turn on the auto save option). I've been having a very complete and really fun experience so far. The price is also really amazing for even the current level of content. I don't expect to make it far enough to see, but the main quest is unfinished. And there are other big upcoming changes, such as more content in the very early game (which you're likely to be seeing a lot of), and eventually different starts. I heard complaints about losing saves, but apparently you can just roll back to the last version thru steam and the save should still be there. I don't tend to like EA, but I'd probably be willing to pay more than the purchase price for the game in it's current form.

23623723.review:
tl;dr Exploratory roguelike with brilliant writing, a huge pool of interesting abilities, and an expansive world to explore.

Caves of Qud! One of the best roguelikes I've ever had the pleasure of playing - I have endless entertaining stories from this game, from the time I knife-fought a bear and won, to the time I set the horrifying Slog on fire and shot lasers from my eyes until he died! (And oh so many amusing deaths, such as the time I was flying over a river, fell into it, and was eaten by madpoles. It's one of those games, see!)

Before I can recommend it, however, I must offer a few caveats: first, most importantly, the learning curve is high for those who aren't used to roguelikes. The GUI is entirely keyboard driven, and having a numpad is highly recommended. There are handy dandy references on display - hit F1, read the quickstart - but you will need to actually read for a little before you're off and running.

Second, character creation will be intimidating when you first run into it. There are so many interesting mutations to take, and so many True Kin classes - don't panic. Pick whatever sounds cool, and marvel at the choices. Take a lot of Toughness, grab freezing hands or light manipulaton, get yourself into the game.

Thirdly, it's still in Early Access. There is a lot of content - there is so much content the devs could stop developing it today (and I'd weep!) but it would still be a full game in its own right, capable of entertaining for hours. The skinny: the main quest line is unfinished. As far as I know, it's roughly halfway done? But: it's difficult and long already, and unless you're really good at roguelikes you won't get to the end of what's in already. (And it will tell you when you hit the end for now.) (Note: the devs are updating it weekly! They revamped caves just recently, and there's even more stuff in the pipeline that hits every friday.)

So, with those caveats in mind, you might be asking - why would I rec this? The answer is: once you learn the ropes and get going, it's one of the best roguelikes out there, and quite possibly the king of the exploratory genre of roguelikes. Caves of Qud is well-written (flavor text abounds!) and has a lovely tileset, and poking around in its jungles and deserts and caves leads to all kinds of fun. There are bears you can talk to in this game, and even bigger, deadlier bears with jetpacks you can die to, for example. There are also actual books in there, Elder Scrolls-style with multiple pages of in-game lore, and those are honestly more exciting to me than the rest of the game, but I'm a lore hound, and I digress.

Once you've poked around the starting town and assigned hotkeys for your numerous abilities, you'll use the world map to either go north to Red Rock or east to the Rust Wells, and there you'll fight in traditional roguelike style - bump against the monster to harm it, on a turn-by-turn basis. Or use your mutant abilities to harm things from afar, or get the multiple arms mutation to dual wield greatswords against your foes. Invest in axes, dismember the limbs of your foes! There are so many interesting options, and the mutations interact in interesting ways as you fight through these distinct areas to get loot and - more importantly - more food and water. Water is the game's currency, and you need both it and food to live. It's a survival sim, in that respect, and you should be careful that you don't go into the desert without food, because you will run out and die of starvation.

Slowly you'll learn where the dangers are - use the look command always to assess your enemies - and you'll learn when to run, or use the big guns in your arsenal. Slowly, you'll forge your way to Grit Gate, and Golgotha, and beyond.

And you'll die. Over and over and over, trying new mutations every time, or just using the "replay most recent character" option until you're sick of playing espers. Caves of Qud, for all it has a learning curve and its brutal difficulty - coaxes you back in by asking you repeatedly: "what if you had this mutation instead?"

It works brilliantly. Please buy this game and enjoy it!

Caves of Qud is a rogue-like RPG, but where it really shines is character creation and experimentation. The idea is that you're set in a world so far into the future that everything is unrecognizeable. That being said, I get the feeling that Qud is meant to be extremely deep. It wants to be a deep and complex world teeming with politics and people. The story (as far as I know) isn't completely finished, and while the new features are very helpful and fun, there is very little attention given to the later stages of the game.

The game is still very fun though.

Pros:
-Faction system makes certain creatures friendly while others might hate you
-Very interesting world with unique lore
-In-depth character creation that makes it exciting to experiment
-Memorable story

Cons:
-Unfinished story
-Mouse input is very limited

Overall, I'd recommend this game. Good value for the price and the developer is a nice guy.
8/10.

19948227.review:
I've often heard that when making a game with retro graphics, one must allow the graphics to fit and even enhance the gameplay. I've actually played a few old-school roguelikes before going to Caves of Qud and in all of them, I felt that a graphical update would improve the gameplay, but Caves of Qud is the first ASCII-roguelike I've ever played where I felt that the graphics did not need an update.

The reason for this is that it shares a huge similarity with older roguelikes in that much of the equipment needs to be identified before you know what it is, but there is a major difference in that when said equipment actually is identified, it immediately becomes apparent that any graphical representation whatsoever would have made it obvious what said object really is to the player. For example, the carbine, a very powerful mid-game rifle. Before identification, the description says, "A strange artifact" but afterwards, it says "A composite carbine with a banana-shaped magazine." If anyone here can make a Fallout game where the average joe could not understand what an assault rifle is without giving the player an unfair and/or non-immersive advantage in identifying it, I would love to see it.

There's also the fact that the lack of linearity and graphical fidelity, and yes, I did just say graphical fidelity, gives you more freedom and better immersion as well as lowering frustation. Very, very few ASCII roguelikes actually have blood splattering on the ground and on many occasions, death can really just creep up on you for no reason. In fact, these graphics hold a special place in my heart for actually being very unnerving in one specific instance, WITH NUMBERS AND LETTERS!!! There's also a major advantage in that if you run into an enemy that you can't fight, you not only get a clear indication of that, you also get options. There are actually other places to grind for XP, which can not be said of most other roguelikes and if a really dangerous enemy won't let up, there are numerous escape options. There is no telling how many times Warden Indrix has saved my characters' life.

Another major difference is how character-building is based less on power-gaming and more on building a character that suits you. Character building for True Men is bog standard but the system really comes alive with mutants. There are various Mental Mutations that give you a great sense of power and Physical Mutations that make your character more likely to end up on DeviantArt. I wish I were kidding, it takes only one mutation point to make your character a f***ing furry. Given that I main as a character with Heightened Hearing, Night Vision, Thick Fur, and has four arms, four legs, and two heads (as well as being amphibious), seeing him as some kind of froggy cattaur with double arms and heads would only be natural.

Lastly, identifying objects is based a lot more on skill and a lot less on luck. On many of the older ASCII roguelikes, dying without knowing what half of your equipment does is just part of the experience and there are many occasions where you can find out that your unidentified equipment could have saved your life. In CoQ however, there is no equipment that is necessary for straightforward identification and no need for sneaksy little tricks for said identification that often left me with 2 dozen tabs open in Firefox just to not be lost. I can not stress the importance of the "Examine" feature enough, it separates this game from all of its peers. Even then, it's not overpowered, you can't "Examine" equipment in merchants' inventories and without the right skillset, "Examine"ing something stands a good chance of breaking it. This can lead to some moments where you really have to gamble on getting something powerful or practically useless to you.

Final Verdict: 10/10 Would accidentally blow most of my fresh water reserves on a box of crayons again.

As someone who plays a lot of Dungeon Crawl: Stone Soup, I came to this game with high expectations. There is a lot of depth of gameplay here, but you're constantly fighting against the User Interface and the way the map works more than the monsters themselves.

You will constantly find yourself bumping into walls you can't see because rather than keeping the game world centered on the player, you're going from screen to screen. The game also seemed to discourage exploring too deep into any given cave - there are dead ends everywhere, and no easy way to backtrack like in most roguelikes. I was very disappointed that there didn't seem to be any way to get back to the surface other than the way I came, forcing me to try to retrace my steps over an hour and a half.

Another issue I had with the game is the performance - you would think such a simple looking game would run smooth as silk, but this game has to stop and think an awful lot. Like many early access titles, this game really needs some optimization done to it, but it's just surprising to see it from a game like this.

I like Caves of Qud quite a lot, and it deserves the positive ratings it has gotten.  However, it is not quite ready for a consumer audience and is quirky enough that it would turn a lot of people off.  I'm writing this "negative" review so that you can understand its shortcomings before buying it.

Caves of Qud is actively in development, with all that entails.  By "development" I do not mean "polish".  There are almost daily updates which sometimes break old savegames.  Mob combat AI is still getting major improvements, items are still being added, large balance changes are made regularly.  The main quest is not finished, some major locations (the kind you can see from the world map) are not finished, and some of the few named unique NPCs have no dialogue.

This is a true early access game, not a beta.  If you are passionate about roguelikes and/or science fiction to the extent that you'd like to help develop the game by finding bugs through hilarious death, you might want in on this.

Beyond its incomplete status, this game is a roguelike.  By genre convention it lacks a great many of the conveniences most gamers are accustomed to.  Input is keyboard-only.  The default keybinds for laptop are both horrible and incomprehensible.  Permadeath is on by default and the disable-permadeath option is somewhat cryptically hidden.  Many enemies can and will destroy you even in starter zones and a "fair fight" is a myth.  You will not always get warnings when steering your character towards certain death.  You will have absurd runs of bad luck that are not your fault and you will die of them.  CoQ makes excellent use of its tile art system, but it's not what most modern gamers will expect.

If you are not comfortable reading books at least a chapter at a time, you will probably not be comfortable playing.  If you cannot occasionally relinquish control and adapt to chance circumstances, you will find this game infuriating.  If you cannot sometimes let go of a good thing, this game might break your heart when your character dies.

This game, overall, has a high barrier to entry.  If you overcome it, though, the world beyond is rich and lovely, as a hundred other reviews will attest.

Caves of Qud is a lovely roguelike with beautiful tile art, a piece of far-future fiction that sci fi fans will immensely enjoy.

17621689.review:
Caves of Qud is a "science-fantasy" roguelike by Freehold Games. It's currently in Early Access, but I've already gotten a lot of hours of enjoyment out of the beta. It has a lot to offer for those who enjoy exploratory dungeon crawling, tense strategic situations, varied playstyles, and a good deal of mystery in their games. Here are some of the highlights, in my opinion:

Character creation: Your character can be created with a huge number of physical and mental mutations, and gain more as you level up. These act as your spells and passive bonuses, and come in a really wide variety of forms. Physically control your adrenal glands for a quick boost of speed in combat, release an EMP to disable enemy grenades and robots, or even manipulate time to produce several clones of yourself. Trying out new combinations of mutations really keeps me coming back to the game. My only real complaint is that, at the time of this review, physical mutations seem less powerful and interesting than mental mutations overall. Rebalancing is sure to come in the future. 

If you're looking for an alternate playstyle, you can also choose for your character to be a "true kin," a non-mutant human who lacks special powers but starts with useful artifacts and higher stats.

The gameplay: True to its genre, Qud has randomly generated levels, randomized loot, and permadeath. If the latter is really a dealbreaker for you, it is possible to turn it off in the "debug" option category. Graphics are either ASCII or a clean, if simple, set of tile icons.

 Unlike other staples of the genre such as Nethack, there is not one ultimate goal (fetch the amulet) but a series of main quests with other objectives you can find on the side. There are also various ways to complete the quests, from what I've seen. Another feature of Qud is the world map, which can be used to quickly travel between locations in the game at the cost of running down your hunger and thirst quicker. 

Enemy balance is pretty good, in my experience: you may run into a really strong monster, but as long as you stop to think, there is usually a way for you to escape and return later.

The world: Caves of Qud takes place in a setting where it seems as if almost anything goes - yet, it's very good at hitting its own specific tone. The weird world of Qud, while putatively post-apocalyptic, has a lot more in common with The Dark Tower than Fallout. The dead civilizations you ransack are [i]old[/i], and the artifacts you dig up range from your everyday hand grenade to more exotic types such as the "shade oil injector," which will cause you to phase out of reality for a little while. I admit I am a bit of a sucker for the trope of forgotten technology aging and turning into artifacts of myth, and Qud does pull it off well. Lore is tantalizingly doled out in item descriptions and NPC dialogue.

Overall, I'm very excited to watch Caves of Qud develop. It's already quite large in scope, and should only be getting better. As another plus, the devs seem to take player feedback very seriously and are active in the forums.

17412804.review:
If I could take one game with me to a desert island, it'd be Caves of Qud. 

**DIFFICULTY**
Is it hard? Yes. 
Is it too hard? No. 
Even for somebody who's never played a roguelike before? Totally do-able. 
You will die. A lot. The game is designed to be hard, but not tear-your-hair-out frustrating. The way that it manages to be very difficult and yet wholly enjoyable despite death after death is a masterpiece of gaming. 

**INTRIGUE**
There is deep political simulation, effecting every last mob in the game. Gain enough reputation with certain types of creatures or people (arachnids, farmers, tortoises) and they will rush to your aid in battle. Lose enough, and they'll attack you on sight. The landmarks in the game--like the starting village, Joppa--are always the same, but the wilderness and caves are procedurally-generated. That means that as you try to reach the deepest depths of, say, Red Rock, you could find the next staircase down mere feet away or on the other side of the map. What's more, there are very in-depth and extremely interesting crafting and trade systems that you can master in time. 

**COMBAT**
Deceptively simple. Like any proper roguelike, you have to come up with creative ways to deal with certain situations. Choosing whether to shoot your rifle or swing your sword could be a life or death decision. It's easy to learn, hard to master. 

**CHARACTER CUSTOMIZATION**
Oh, boy. Wanna be a beguilin', time-dilatin', flame-throwin', photosynthesizin', gunslingin' cowboy-snake called Grassy Jones? You got it. 
Want to be one of just a few remaining true men, an aristocrat as well versed in ways of the trigger as he is in the way of the blade? You got it.  
Wanna get a few more points to put into useful mutations by taking a debuff that puts an evil twin somewhere in the world, an exact clone of your character who may one day find you and kill you? Yep. You can do that too. 

**LORE**
Just play it, man. It's awesome. 

**CONS**
Sometimes, you get attached to your beguilin', time-dilatin', flame-throwin', photosynthesizin', gunslingin' cowboy-snake called Grassy Jones. While after he dies you can click 'replay most recent character' on the new game screen and get Grassy Jones back, you won't get his successes back. Half the time, that's fine and it's just as fun to do it all over again. There's actually a disable permadeath button, but for now it doesn't work. There are other little cons, but they're too small to mention. 

**THE BEST PART**
It ain't even finished yet, cowboy.

17232460.review:
STORY/SETTING:
The environment and world that this game is set in are awesome. A post-apocalyptic setting done right with a minimum of over-used tropes is the backdrop for your adventure. You begin as a hapless adventurer simply trying to make your way in life, but can progress (with a little luck and a little skill) into a wealthy and powerful figure with an ever-increasing knowledge of the mysterious world in which you live and its exciting ancient past. 10/10.

UI:
Once you grasp the basics of the control scheme, the game becomes easier and easier to play. I personally enjoy the all-keyboard control scheme of a well-made roguelike, as it allows me to play the entire game with no more hand motion than it takes me to write this review. This setup can be daunting for newcomers to the roguelike genre or even to experienced dungeon crawlers who are new to this game in particular. The complete lack of mouse support, even in the menus, has been off-putting at times; however, there is an option in one of the menus that claims to activate mouse interactivity (though it seems to do nothing at the time). Perhaps the developers are planning on introducing this feature at some point in the future.
The game includes no tutorial for the controls, so a new player has to do some reading and some perusing of the hotkey binding page before they can make much progress in the game. I would hope that at some point in the future the devs introduce some sort of tutorial mode to help out with this.
Overall, once the controls are mastered and the GUI is understood by the player, it is a system on par with what i would expect from a commercial roguelike, though it could definitely be daunting to a newbie and has no tutorial to explain its intricacies. 6/10.

GAMEPLAY:
As with the UI, there is no particular gameplay tutorial to help the player become immersed in the game. There are walls of text in the help menus that can, with patience, teach you enough about the game to get started. From there, you're on your own. In some ways, this is interesting, as it forces you to discover each new fact about the game world for yourself, rather than having it spoonfed to you. In other ways, it is frustrating. For example: it took me until my second or third character to understand that _water is the currency_ in this game. The confusion was due in large part to water's being represented by the $ sign in various interfaces.
That all being said, once one gets a grasp of the flow of gameplay, it's a wonderful experience that melds with the world and makes me want to play more and more. The procedurally generated game world also draws me in, as I know that playing the game will never simply become a matter of rote memorization. (Has anyone else played 400+ hours of Skyrim? Then you know the feeling.) Overall, 8/10.

CHARACTER OPTIONS:
The other daunting aspect for a new player is the sheer volume of choices to make at character creation, with no particular guidance besides (eventually) experience. Again, interesting in that one has to descover working character builds for themselves, but not newbie friendly. This item is double edged though: I have to say that I love nothing more than a system that gives me a full spectrum of options in character creation, especially in a world where having "4 unique classes" is a selling point in some games.
In addition to the countless myriad of unique characters that can be created before one even enters the world, the game also features a robust skills tree that allows the player to uniquely customize their character. This skills tree does more than simply "Add 5 to hit with longswords". 17176523.review:
Think Cardinal Quest meets Brogue

~Features
Turn-based combat
ASCII graphics
Procedurally generated* world (*Static locations, such as the starting area.) 
Impressive character creation / customization
Variety of enemies, NPCs, factions and races
Solid economy 
Day and night cycle
Permadeath
Local high-scores / graveyard

Caves of Qud, despite forming a terrible acronym also forms a well-written and discursive love letter to the Rogue game, and the '-like' genre it spawned.

While heavily inspired by original rogue-likes (not least in its graphical style) it features the kind of complex, esoteric lore more commonly found in modern rogue-likes and '-lites'. With little to no explanation and zilch in the way of a tutorial, the game rewards trial and error, while laughing in the faces of those impatient or easily enraged.

The starting area of Joppa, is static and you will always start 'here', there are characters to talk to and some early missions to be had. Being the permadeath-fest that it is, the lack of a dynamic starting point may become repetitive to you, but I found it as a haven upon which to launch my next doomed-to-fail attempt, at discovering just what the hell I was supposed to be doing. 
Joppa, described as an oasis-village, is such. A ray of familiarity in an otherwise blotched out world of unpredictability.

COQ (hehe), features heavy RPG elements and levelling is a requirement. This, in-spite of the frequent permadeath and subsequent character creation, never feels too 'grindy'.
I found myself encouraged to try one more run, rather than put off by a lacking sense of achievement.

Asking price is fair, in my opinion. Though edging on steep when judged against its competition. There is a free version (minus the minimalistic tile-set) floating about, so you can try before you commit to supporting its further development.

In conclusion, Caves of Qud is a true rogue-like with very few bells but a whole bag of whistles. For those with the constitution, a rich and open ended experience awaits.

I picked this up because I was intrigued by the science-fantasy setting: the game takes place on what is presumably Earth, far in the future, amidst the ruins of a long-dead civilization that is now long dead, with the remnants of humanities scattered between various tribes and feudal holdfasts. It's a nice mix of ancient sensibilities and high-tech sorcery that hearkens back to a bygone era of pulp sci-fi.

Upon starting the game proper, I was pleasantly surprised by the level of customization permitted during character creations - mutant characters get the brunt of the options, in the forms of various mutations which can vary from small stat bonuses to special combat abilities to mutations that can drastically change the way the game is played. Pure humans, on the other hand, get to pick from one of several classes that will decide their starting skills and gear.

On entering the game world and getting into the thick of it, I somehow found my way to the faction page and found out that not only does each phylum of the animal kingdom have its own faction but that they're all after my blood, with the sole exception of the antelopes, with whom I've somehow managed to maintain cordial relations. On one of my trips to the beginners' dungeon, I was beset upon and ruthlessly torn apart by a pack of baboons, quickly confirming the faction screen's insinuations. The gameplay is the usual roguelike fare - delving into dungeons and fending off ravenous furries, robots and said fauna, collecting treasure (swords, axes, woven bracelets, shotguns, high-tech gizmos and combat drugs) and gaining levels.

The skill system in this game is well done - rather than gaining small incremental bonuses for pumping points into skills, every available upgrade to your skills carries a discrete benefit and/or ability. For example, when upgrading the long blades skill, you can choose the interception ability, which gives you a small chance of attacking any enemy that moves into an adjacent space for free and an activated stance that ensures you automatically intercept for a number of turns. The fact that gaining skills and growing in power actually affords new tactical opportunities rather than just embiggening numbers is one of this game's definite strengths. The huge amount of possible combinations of gear, stats, mutations and abilities mean that you'll have limitless options as to how to build your character.

Also rather unusually for a roguelike, this game has quests, and what appears to be a storyline. One downside is that those I've encountered so far appear to be fixed and do not vary from playthrough to playthrough, which does detract from the novelty a bit. I've not yet played far enough to tell for sure, but it does appear that they can be safely skipped, for the most part, though my compulsive nature has lead them to feeling more like chores to be repeated after each death rather than the interesting opportunities they were at first.

As for the simulation aspects, I'm not rightly sure how deep they go. It's certainly nowhere near Dwarf Fortress adventure mode's level of granular simulation, as numerous elements appear to stay the same across different playthroughs, and some things appear to not be simulated at all. This isn't a bad thing, however, since in lieu of DF's maniacal obsession with detail, this game provides basic gameplay mechanics that are far more fun, it runs better, and not having to rely on generated conversations and descriptions allows the devs to infuse it with far more flavour and atmosphere, creating an experience which is a lot more coherent and quite a bit less samey than DF's adventure mode.

Overall, I've played this game for only 4 hours as of writing this, and I've only explored a miniscule corner of the game world. If you like Roguelikes and RPGs in general, this game is a steal at 10 bucks. My only complaint is the unremovable CRT filter and the low contrast colour settings, which I've admittedly grown used to by now, but which I'd still rather turn off if I were given the option.

I've had a positive review up for ages, but looked and saw it wasn't very specific. so let's clarify!

CoQ has been releasing free builds for at least six years, and went live on Steam in, eh, late 2015? the first thing to note about it is that, unlike most roguelikes in a similar graphical style, it has a thoroughly user-friend interface, and in fact the graphics are clear enough that even someone like me who can never bother to try could read it in ASCII. that's no longer necessary, as the released version sports a very stylish and stylized tileset, but it speaks to the deliberateness of the design.

that relative transparency is all over in CoQ. important mechanics aren't usually obfuscated; a piece of armor modifies your damage resistance and your dodge chance, and if it does anything else, a quick examination will tell you what it is. dialogue plays out as trees rather than keyword guessing, and you're given clear guidance on how to get going right out of the gate, while also having several directions you can go--or being free to wander on your own. the game is narrative and lore is plentiful, its far-future apocalypse rich in a kind of charming strangeness that pulls off the trick of never winking at itself. these characters genuinely do live in a weird and mostly posthuman world.

one of the earliest jobs you're sent on is named for Canticle for Liebowitz, and you can definitely see that in the tone. the wreckage of ancient technology's everywhere, sometimes an object of worship, sometimes of study, sometimes of something in between, but people who understand it are eccentrics. you'll occasionally come across a tome that describes some menacing discovery in pure science from the distant past and implies with gloriously heady and incoherent diction just how the world was saved from that dark knowledge. the world's at once ruined and lively. and when you go into the jungle and the recently-added ambient tracks kick in, you'll realize it's filled with menace, too.

if there's a criticism to be laid at Qud's feet, it's that it can be hard. character build guides can go a long way to help with that--the freeform system mean it's easy to build a character who's useless, although there are still tons of ways to build one who's useful--but ultimately until you've spent a bit of time with the game you're still going to be stepping on plants that impale you and end a run you though was promising. recycling your previous build is generally pretty easy, but going through the motions of starting out can be a tiny bit annoying--reassigning whatever psychic powers you chose to take to keybindings, running around town to pick up whatever randomly-spawned loot you've got this time. ultimately, though, these are small and self-afflicted tribulations, and do nothing to diminish what I feel is the best roguelike around.

Ok. If youre a fan of true Roguelikes- not the games that have random generation and permadeath and so are labeled "roguelike" just based on that fact - but real true top down randomly generated RPGs that use keyboard commands, have a  ton of variable randomly generated content and options, turn based, simple tile graphics but are incredibly complex and fun, then  you MUST get this game. Its been around for a bit in a free ASCII format, but this is the new and improved and worth paying for version.

Its great. I used to play the ASCII Roguelikes back in the day (Moria, *Angband etc), but Ive gotten to the point where I like tiles. And CoQ has them. Simple tiles, yes, and they aren't all done. But at least you're not squinting and trying to remember if the blue s was a simple water snake or a terrible siren that will charm you before she beats you to death.

Theres no sound ort music yet, but that is something that the devs are planning on putting in.
Unlike most Roguelikes. this one is Sci Fi/Fantasy, which is cool. It reminds me of a sci-fi-ish DarkSun, that awesome D&D world from the '90s. Qud appears to be a ruined dry world, full of sentient plants, caves, little water, ancient tech, giant insects etc. Its really unique and fun.

Theres two races, mutated human and True Kin each with a HUGE amount of unique-to-that-race sub options to really customize your PC. Mutated Humans are weaker than True Kin but get mutation points. The points allow them to buy physical or mental mutations (positive traits) and defects, which are detrimental but give you more mutation points. I dont know how many mutations and defects you can choose from, but it looks like at least 70 or so. Mutants also get 12 classes to choose from, and none of them are like "fighter" "mage" "priest". They are all unique, nomads, tinkers, merchants, wardens etc. True Kin have better starting attributes, no mutations and can choose 1  of 12 "castes" (classes - again they are pretty unique), also choosing a caste chooses the arcology you come from. There are 3 arcologies, each with 4 castes. THey appear to be the "shut away in the high-tech place protected from the wasteland" type race, while the Mutants are the "scrabbling dirt-grubbers trying to survive in the toxic wastelands".

The world is HUGE and expansive, even in its unfinished state. Theres also a main storyline, another thing most Roguelikes lack (beyond the "get to the bottom of the dungeon and bring the Amulet of Yendor back out" type plots), in addition to the "bring me a whatzit from the wherezit" type quests you see in many Roguelikes tkat actually have towns and NPCs you can talk to.

The game is still in EA, and the devs are adding more content and bugstomping. The main questline isnt finished, But even in EA, its totally worth picking up. I never buy EA games, I usually wishlist them until completion. But Ive seen "full release" games that werent this complex and fun.

"Oh shit," I think to myself as crocodile bites into my flesh. I assumed that I could beat the glorified lizard like I could in so many other games. I was wrong. This was just the first of many deaths I would experience in my first couple of hours with the game.

TL;DR at the bottom.

I'm an unabashed fan of roguelikes. The focus on character building and death meaning something have always been a huge draw to me. If you look at my library, I have a lot of these suckers. You may wonder if there's still games in the genre that can still surprise me. The answer is HELL YES. Caves of Qud is one such game.

Throw out the typical fantasy setting you probably picture when you think of a roguelike. This is the post-apocalypse and your two choices are to play as a pure or mutated human. I've tried both and the latter seems to be way more fun. It kind of reminds me of the episodes of Futurama with the mutants in the sewer. You can turn yourself into all kinds of monstrosities, and I suspect the number of options will only grow over time. My most recent playthrough I decided to take a mutation which gave me flaming hands. I didn't realize it meant I would never be able to wear gloves. This is a great illustration of the mutation system: most of the time it involves trade offs, especially for the really fun powers, like being made up of quills like a porcupine (a personal favorite).

The graphics are ASC, but put through a filter that makes it look like you're playing on a much older computer. One that may or may not be from before your time. I personally love the look of it, but the result makes it deceptively system intensive. 

The controls will be divisive to the say the least. Some will be pissed that the controls are so obtuse, though once you play with them for a while they do start to feel natural. They can all be rebound though, and if you're willing to put in the effort to do so you can bind them in any way that your heart desires!

I haven't even explored a fraction of the world yet, nor have I managed to complete the first quest I was given. There are still enemies that would seem menial in other games that can kill me if I'm not careful. Call me a masochist but this is more than a little bit exciting to me. Two hours into a game I generally feel like I get what's going on, but here I'm still trying to figure out what exactly I'm supposed to do. The procedurally generated, fully destructable world is huge, and I get the feeling that even without permadeath (that is an option for those who are turned off by having to reroll all the time) the game would be collosal.

If you're into that kind of thing, there's tons of lore here too. More than I'll ever manage to sift through realistically. It's a world of mutants and sentient bears; the writing ain't half bad either.

Negatives are that the game uses far more system resources than it needs to. It looks pretty, but functionality trumps graphics, especially in a roguelike. Also, the game isn't friendly to those who aren't willing to be patient with it. You'll die a lot before you start to see successes. Then you'll continue to die frequently. That can be disheartening and will certainly put off some players. This game is harder than Nethack in my opinion, and that's not something I would say lightly. Tutorials would be a welcome feature, more than just a series of paragraphs to read in the help section.

TL;DR: This is the roguelike for the true hardcore roguelike player. It's tough, it's massive, and inventive enough that I feel like telling my friends about the porcupine-beetle-man hybrid that I rolled last time. For an early access title its chock full of content. Check it out, but just be ready to die.

Alright, time for a seriousness edit:

Caves of Qud is a traditional-style roguelike, set in a fallout-esque world a few thousand years after the end of the world. It's got plenty of procedurally generated caves and ruins to explore scattered across a large overworld, all tied together by a quest line rife with side-quests. At least, that's what it aims to be eventually; currently, the main quest line is not finished, and many side quests remain unimplemented as of the writing of this review. Despite this, there's tons of content to discover and die by.

Even though the quest line is unfinished, you will die many, many times before you reach the end (you'll know when it stops, if you make it that far). The difficulty and frequency of death allows you to explore the rich character creation system the game is packing. This system offers many options, allowing you to choose whether you begin as a mutant (slower skill point gain, but gains useful mutations) or a True Man (higher starting attributes, and increased skill point gain). From there, you've got a number of physical/mental mutations (for mutants) or castes (for True Men) to choose from. Additionally, Qud offers you a skill tree of sorts as you level up, allowing you to gain abilities as you grow more experienced. Oh, and dialogue trees!

Though it may be difficult to get in to, Caves of Qud offers a unique,engaging, and deeply rewarding rpg experience. I wholeheartedly recommend it to people interested in the genre, or to anyone interested in being mauled by a sleepy panther-bear because they spontaneously combusted while sneaking past it.
